column8:
Most of what the reviews are saying is true. EA tried to do something different this time and it didn't please everyone. My verdict is that this game is probably more fun for casual gamers and not serious RTS players. The gameplay was definitely watered down from the previous installments. I am a loyal C&C fan, so I wanted to play it to keep up with the overall storyline and check out some of the units.

PROS:
1. I did not think the units were that cartoony. I was impressed to see how they advanced. 
A. TITANS are back. Got to love mechs! Everything is bigger and more mechanized than before.
2. Excellent graphics that don't require a super expensive graphics card.
3. Classes can be fun to play and less stressful if you are a casual player. The whole game is very relaxed for a C&C game. I realize this is not the intent of most RTS games. Lol

CONS
1. Acting is awkward and stiff. Eg; Commander's wife.
2. While I like the soundtrack somewhat better than C&C 3's, it will never measure up to Frank Klepacki's backing tracks.
3. Mobile MCV game style is annoying. I miss building bases.
4. Female voice overs are annoying. I think it was clear the devs are trying to boast girl power, which I dislike and am strongly against having this kind of undertone in one of my favorite games.

5. The plot is interesting enough, but not great. It is all about the containment of tiberium on Earth and Nod forces are cooperating with, but also betraying, GDI forces. This is sort of a repeat of some of the last game's storyline. There are no scrin in this game because they had been pushed out and retreated in the last game. Still, it would have been more interesting to see them return. I guess this leaves room for a potential C&C5.

column8:
Always online, always glitchy graphics, always crashes.
Braindead gameplay, base building is gone, energy is gone and tiberium is gone. Units are free and there's a unit cap now, it's extremely low, so you're just throwing a handful of units at each other to see who wins.
Units are also separated into 3 classes for some reason, you can only build one subset of all units.
The damage model is confusing, heavy weapons do less damage to light vehicles than light weapons? I don't get it.
The story is so bad it's just taking the piss, just referencing random things and persons from the games without much care about previous lore.

column8:
This game likely wouldn’t have received so much hate if the developers hadn’t included the "4" in the title. It should have been treated as a spin-off rather than a direct continuation of the series.

I won’t lie, I actually like the gameplay concept. It’s fun and less stressful, which is about the only thing I genuinely enjoy about this game.

What Doesn’t Work for Me?

1. Cringeworthy Storyline
The storyline is painfully awkward. Was it really necessary to add a romance subplot? Every time I see a cutscene where the commander (player) interacts with his wife, I cringe. The worst moment comes at the end of the NOD campaign when she cries over her hubby's death. It just feels so forced and unnatural.

2. Disappointing Music
The soundtrack is a letdown. The GDI music is passable, but the NOD tracks completely miss the mark. Instead of capturing NOD’s signature dark and intense vibe, it sounds more like tribal chanting from some random village in Kuvukiland.

3. Strange Unit Scaling
The proportions of some units are way off. Certain vehicles are unnecessarily large.. take The Forgotten's "school bus" for example. It’s somehow the same size as a Mammoth Tank, which is just ridiculous.

4. Weak Sound Design
The weapon sounds are underwhelming. Guns, cannons, rockets—none of them have the impact they should. Even the legendary Obelisk of Light no longer gives off that powerful "ZWEEENG" sound. And the rocket visuals? They're so tiny, they look more like fireworks than deadly projectiles.

At the end of the day, I know I’m wasting time reviewing a 15-year-old game that will never get updated. But still, what a missed opportunity.

column8:
NOTE: This is NOT Command & Conquer. 

I read a whole mess of the reviews after I purchased this "game" via the "Ultimate Collection."
They're right. They're all right... Well, the negative ones anyway. 

Here's how my experience went:
1) Launcher wants you to sign in with your EA account... [Ok, fine.]
2) Error... [Fuck]
3) Error persists seeming at random. [What THE fuck?]
4) Suddenly it's all fine for the game to start up. Nothing changed.  [Riiiiiight...]
5) A different login asking for the same information... [Ooookaaay?]
6) Pretty cool looking loading screen... [but why is it all blue?]
7) Start skirmish. [Oh... Oh god no.]
8) Exit and delete.

I absolutely DO NOT recommend purchasing this thing. It's very much bottom of the barrel for EA.
As I said at the top, it is NOT C&C. It's some base-level cash in. I have B-grade mobile games with more RTS soul than this.

To those running EA, I hope L*igi gets out and takes great offence to your actions.

column8:
Yeah, no
I really wanted to give this one a go after all these years. My 1st experience was awful playing this since my friend got me a pirated version of this from the local market and it is on 4 discs. Had a lot of "fun" installing it and cracking it all for it to be a C&C without base building, xp grinding and a boring C&C campaign both story and mission structure due to the nature of walking "bases".
The soundtrack is even not that good compared to other C&C games somehow... how did they manage to mess that up?
Clearly this was meant to be a Online Only game for Asian players and it shows. Kind of reminds me of the saddly failed attempt at Company Of Heroes Online which was kind of awesome honestly.

It doesn't work most of the time, even on EA app and when it works it is just not fun. Reminds me of the Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak due to its gameplay style, but worse.

column8: EA why?? you screw up the login? EA today uses the EA app and I don't see why this game should be different and most of the bad reviews are about the login, I did get it to work eventually and if anyone is having the same problem there are guides on steam that can help you get the game to load. Personally I have always been a fan of the CNC series and this is the first time on CNC 4 the game can take some getting used too as it uses an entirely different system set into offence, defence, support and the main command centre is mobile making the whole game more challenging than previous titles, most people seem to dislike this way of playing a CNC game but after playing for awhile it can make for some really interesting game play it just takes some time getting used to. The graphics are much better then previous titles and you get a real sense of elevation and differences in the maps terrain, the units range from small to massive and the names are different from previous titles. The sounds is not bad and i like them as it gives that CNC feel to the game. Overall people don't like the login which is understandable and they find it to challenging were as if you grind you can get through the levels and also they don't like the online service that does not have anyone available however I have found at certain times it is populated. I give the game 8/10 for graphics 8/10 for sounds and 8/10 for game play overall 8/10 as is a good game if you take the time to adjust to the new system but the login should be scrapped.

column8:
Kupiłem gre na Steam. I co?
Launcher: Error(Ogólny błąd systemu)
A jak nie Launcher, a gra jedna się uruchamia to i tak nie wpuszcza do menu z powodu jakiejś nie zgodności.
Nagrałem się...
Mogę życzyć kierownictwu EA by żarli krwawą zupę na obiad!
Hańba to co zrobili z serią CNC oraz to jak sama ta gra jest nie grywalna, wejść do niej się nie da.
Ale przyznam, że gdy grałem kiedyś piracką wersję i tam w singleplayer odblokowałem większość technologii to przy kolejnej rozgrywce atakującym można było zrobić wspaniały szyk wraz z MSC i wszystkich rozwalać.
column9:
I bought the game on Steam. So what?
Launcher: Error (General System Error)
And if it's not the Launcher, and the game itself launches, it still won't let you into the menu due to some incompatibility.
I recorded myself...
I wish EA management would eat blood soup for dinner!
It's a disgrace what they did with the CNC series, and the fact that the game itself is unplayable; it's impossible to get into it.
But I admit that when I played a pirated version once and unlocked most of the technology in single-player, the next time the attackers could form a great formation with MSC and destroy everyone.

column8:
to launch cnc4 in 2025 on win10. servers are closed, but u can play it in single player.
1. go to install folder, click Properties on cnc4.exe, in compability tab check Run as administrator, click apply, ok.
2. create new EA.com account in web browser. password must be exactly 8 symbols, 1 big letter at least and 1 number at least. only letters and numbers.
3. launch the game with cnc4.exe in files folder. when promped by windows to make chages, click yes - allow.
4. type email for ur new ea account and password
5. choose some ingame name that is not already taken, click PLay.
6. when cutscene starts, press Esc to skip it.
7. when u see another login screen, alt +tab to desktop, find Windows Firewall promt for cnc4 and click OK - Allow access to internet.
8. Again enter email and password for ur new ea account.

i saw 7 ppl online in chat. 1 responded. we launched coop campaign mission. nothing else works. no custom skirmish, no coop automatch, no pvp, no coop vs ai. only coop campaign with other players.  have not testes single player. maybe can lauch skirmish solo.

the campaign mission crashed the game in middle of mission. will try to lower graphics settings.

column8: Un seguito un pò bruttino di una saga che veramente meritava qualcosa di più. ormai è invecchiato male anche solo per l'aspetto grafico che quando uscì era l'unico aspetto decente. meglio i vecchi capitoli. io l'ho finito all'epoca e ripreso dp anni, ma dp 2 ore di gioco qui su steam sono stato costretto a lasciarlo. non l ho amato all'uscita e non l ho fatto in un secondo momento purtroppo.
column9: A somewhat ugly sequel to a saga that truly deserved something more. It's aged poorly, even just because of the graphics, which were the only decent aspect when it came out. The older installments are better. I finished it back then and picked it up again years later, but after 2 hours of gameplay here on Steam, I was forced to abandon it. I didn't love it when it came out, and unfortunately, I didn't do it again later.

Если вы знакомы с серией Тибериумных войн, для вас наверное не секрет, что эти стратегии завораживают. Четвёртая часть выпущена на новом движке, да и сама суть игры претерпела ряд изменений: не нужно теперь зарабатывать деньги, не нужно строить базы (оборонительный краулер - исключение, но об этом позже), стройцентр или штаб теперь заменили краулеры, которые совмещают все функции базы в себе. Краулеры бывают оборонные, наступательные и поддержки. По сути - игра сводится к скорейшему созданию юнитов и их быстрейшей прокачке. Количество бойцов ограничено, только в этом и сложность.

If If you're familiar with the Tiberium Wars series, it's probably no secret that these strategy games are captivating. The fourth installment is released on a new engine, and the core of the game has undergone a number of changes: there's no longer any need to earn money or build bases (the defensive crawler is an exception, but more on that later). The construction center or headquarters have been replaced by crawlers, which combine all the functions of a base. Crawlers can be defensive, offensive, or supportive. Essentially, the game boils down to quickly creating units and leveling them up. The number of units is limited, and that's the only challenge.

column8:
This game managed to kill even the messiah.

But I still give it a thumbs up for having nailed something perfectly: the end time atmosphere.

Perhaps not in the way intended. But in a meta sense, that, in a strange twist of abstraction, made it even better. So, yeah. We witnessed a real death here. It's over, folks. It's over.

column8:
[h1][i]“Peace through powe... 💥”[/i]
~Kane[/h1]

So, overwhelmingly negative status, huh? You don't see that often. Also, it's a well-known fact that this game is a series killer. That's right. One of the most influential and important series for the RTS genre, the one that shaped and defined it the way we know it today was destroyed by this little fella here. How did that happen? To understand that we should first go for a quick summary.

1992 – [b]Dune II[/b] is released. Based on [b]David Lynch[/b]'s adaptation of [b]Frank Herbert[/b]'s novel, it introduced series' core gameplay. We were collecting [b]Spice[/b] with out harvester vehicles to earn credits and then spending those credits to build ourselves base and an army. 1995 – the first [b]C&C[/b] is made. While being spiritual successor of [b]Dune II[/b], the game had much more serious tone, while also including FMV elements. 1996 – [b]Red Alert[/b]. Pretty much the same thing with [b]C&C[/b], just with some improvements, naval battles [i]and[/i] an important backstory to [b]C&C[/b] villain – [b]Kane[/b], who was revealed as evil mastermind behind the humanity's major history events. 1997 – [b]Sole Survivor[/b]. Failed attempt for online-only deathmatch experience based on the original [b]C&C[/b] game.

1999 – [b]Tiberian Sun[/b]. The first game after [b]EA[/b] acquisition. Originally planned as much more complicated project, it ended up feeling a bit rushed, but still, in many ways it was a sequel everybody waited for. 2000 – [b]Red Alert 2[/b]. Made mostly by new members under [b]EA[/b], it rebooted the [b]RA[/b] series. Shared universe was no more. 2002 – [b]Renegade[/b]. Failed attempt to make next-gen mixture between RTS and FPS genres. 2003 – [b]Generals[/b]. The first game after the series' creators were shut down by [b]EA[/b]. Rather weird attempt to reboot series by dropping the old lore and altering core mechanics from [b]Dune II[/b]. 2007 – [b]C&C3[/b]. A pretty smart U-turn for the series that brought it back to its roots and felt a lot like remake of the 1995 game. 2008 – [b]Red Alert 3[/b]. A consoles-oriented game that felt more like [b]Generals 2[/b] and also introduced us to co-op. Thanks to which it felt more like online-oriented spin-off. Yet it was a very good game that lots of people loved. And [i]that[/i] was the beginning of the end.

How's the good game is a bad thing you may ask? You see, it made [b]EA[/b] believe that quick online sessions is what people wanted. You may expect them to learn from [b]Sole Survivor[/b]'s failure, but it was an ancient history, while at the moment [b]RA3[/b] was selling really well, so... Yeah. [b]C&C4[/b] was planned as a co-op-oriented project. Which... Isn't a bad thing per se. I mean, [b]RA3[/b] was good, right? Unfortunately, the fact that people swallowed [b]RA3[/b] being more [b]Generals[/b] than the original [b]C&C[/b], gave [b]EA[/b] another idea. An idea that... *SIGH* But OK, let's finally take a proper look at what we've got. And what we've got is... Anything but [b]C&C[/b].

I know, I know, it comes from a person who keeps saying that [b]Generals[/b] was not really [b]C&C[/b], but this here? It took every single [b]C&C[/b] element and flushed 'em down the toilet. Resource gathering? Believe it or not, it's no more. Remember the days we were arguing about [b]Generals[/b] having resource management similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] instead of our usual [b]Dune II[/b] thing? Well, resources are no more. No resources – no problem by [b]EA[/b] logic. Technically, [b]Tiberium[/b] ([b]C&C[/b]'s counterpart of [b]Spice[/b]) is still here, but it's just some crystals you'll be able to pick up now and then to upgrade units. Like I said, resource gathering? Not a thing. And so is a base building. Again, remember that old argument about how in [b]Generals[/b] we were able to build anywhere (similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] too), while “real” [b]C&C[/b] was all about the construction yard and things we were building around it? In this game we can't build at all. Well, technically, there [i]is[/i] one building. And the whole game revolves around it.

Everybody who played [b]C&C[/b] is familiar with the [b]MCV[/b]. So-called mobile construction vehicle was pretty much a portable construction yard. The original idea was to let us choose place for our new base to get the advantage we wanted. Now? Now it's more like our portable all-in-one base. Not only we can move it at any time ([b]StarCraft[/b] anyone?), it also acts like all other buildings from previous games. We build units, we purchase upgrades, we use powers... You've got the idea. Our whole base is just that – one fat [b]MCV[/b]. Where do we get money to produce units, you may ask? Well, that's a very good question, because in this game? You don't need money. You're free to build as many units as you want. There's a very strict population limit now, though, much more strict than in those [b]BLIZZARD[/b] titles. But that's just a thing. Forget about those big armies. Our goal in this game is, while only having a few units, to figure out perfect combination to outsmart our enemy.

But OK, you may say that simplified take on [b]Company of Heroes[/b], while not being a [b]C&C[/b] at all, may still be a good game. True. And that's where our second problem comes in. See, [b]C&C4[/b] is not a well-made product. Not even thought-through. The first thing you'll notice after the initial shock is... how hard this game is. Which... isn't even true. The problem is – single player campaign here is tied to your online profile. Remember the challenges from [b]RA3[/b] expansion? The ones, where you started with close to no technologies (units)? That's the stuff. You start single player campaign with nothing. Yet doing some skirmish grinding first will make it much easier. And a lot of grinding? You guessed it, there are no limits. Grind for the highest commander level (may take quite some time, especially since [b]GDI[/b] and [b]Nod[/b] are leveled separately) and get big advantage for your single player experience. What. The f*ck? Pretty sure single player experience implies dealing with properly calculated conditions. Here? It's a lot like playing story in some MMO. You stuck? Go grind somewhere else and come back later. Like I said, WTF?

Thankfully, most likely, you won't even get a chance to suffer through all that. Why? *SIGH* Did you play [b]Anthem[/b], guys? [b]C&C4[/b] was exactly that long before it. Starting [b]C&C4[/b] goes like this – launch the game, enter login and password for your [b]EA[/b] account, get an error, change password to fit eight symbols (don't ask me why) and voilà! The game works. Is it, though? Right after launch you'll be asked to enter login and password [i]again[/i]. Only this time even the short password won't help. Why? Because you need to have [b]EA[/b] app running on background. Again, don't ask me why (it doesn't look like the game interacts with it). Even after all that, there's still a chance for a game to tell you to go f*ck yourself. Hello, [b]Anthem[/b]. How you doin'?

So here we are. Not only this game dropped everything that we fell in love back in 1992, it also feels rushed (naturally, it's buggy and imbalanced too) and, well, it's half-broken. And it's all pretty sad, you know? The atmosphere here is quite solid. Moreover, the story is quite creative. It has FMV cutscenes, it's told from the first-person perspective and we, the commander, are the main character. The one who plays the most important role. We [i]finally[/i] got [b]Kane[/b] explained, there [i]is[/i] a proper ending for the [b]Tiberium[/b] saga... Sure, it's too short (game only has seven missions per faction), but still, with some proper gameplay, it'll be quite enjoyable. Unfortunately, [b]C&C4[/b] is a mixture of the unfortunate coincidences and bad decisions. When you look back, you see that such a mistake was inevitable. But it [i]is[/i] [b]EA[/b]'s fault that shot ended up being deadly. Dixi.
column9:
[h1][i]“Peace through powe... 💥”[/i]
~Kane[/h1]

So, overwhelmingly negative status, huh? You don't see that often. Also, it's a well-known fact that this game is a series killer. That's right. One of the most influential and important series for the RTS genre, the one that shaped and defined it the way we know it today was destroyed by this little fella here. How did that happen? To understand that we should first go for a quick summary.

1992 – [b]Dune II[/b] is released. Based on [b]David Lynch[/b]'s adaptation of [b]Frank Herbert[/b]'s novel, it introduced series' core gameplay. We were collecting [b]Spice[/b] with out harvester vehicles to earn credits and then spending those credits to build ourselves base and an army. 1995 – the first [b]C&C[/b] is made. While being spiritual successor of [b]Dune II[/b], the game had much more serious tone, while also including FMV elements. 1996 – [b]Red Alert[/b]. Pretty much the same thing with [b]C&C[/b], just with some improvements, naval battles [i]and[/i] an important backstory to [b]C&C[/b] villain – [b]Kane[/b], who was revealed as evil mastermind behind the humanity's major history events. 1997 – [b]Sole Survivor[/b]. Failed attempt for online-only deathmatch experience based on the original [b]C&C[/b] game.

1999 – [b]Tiberian Sun[/b]. The first game after [b]EA[/b] acquisition. Originally planned as much more complicated project, it ended up feeling a bit rushed, but still, in many ways it was a sequel everybody waited for. 2000 – [b]Red Alert 2[/b]. Made mostly by new members under [b]EA[/b], it rebooted the [b]RA[/b] series. Shared universe was no more. 2002 – [b]Renegade[/b]. Failed attempt to make next-gen mixture between RTS and FPS genres. 2003 – [b]Generals[/b]. The first game after the series' creators were shut down by [b]EA[/b]. Rather weird attempt to reboot series by dropping the old lore and altering core mechanics from [b]Dune II[/b]. 2007 – [b]C&C3[/b]. A pretty smart U-turn for the series that brought it back to its roots and felt a lot like remake of the 1995 game. 2008 – [b]Red Alert 3[/b]. A consoles-oriented game that felt more like [b]Generals 2[/b] and also introduced us to co-op. Thanks to which it felt more like online-oriented spin-off. Yet it was a very good game that lots of people loved. And [i]that[/i] was the beginning of the end.

How's the good game is a bad thing you may ask? You see, it made [b]EA[/b] believe that quick online sessions is what people wanted. You may expect them to learn from [b]Sole Survivor[/b]'s failure, but it was an ancient history, while at the moment [b]RA3[/b] was selling really well, so... Yeah. [b]C&C4[/b] was planned as a co-op-oriented project. Which... Isn't a bad thing per se. I mean, [b]RA3[/b] was good, right? Unfortunately, the fact that people swallowed [b]RA3[/b] being more [b]Generals[/b] than the original [b]C&C[/b], gave [b]EA[/b] another idea. An idea that... *SIGH* But OK, let's finally take a proper look at what we've got. And what we've got is... Anything but [b]C&C[/b].

I know, I know, it comes from a person who keeps saying that [b]Generals[/b] was not really [b]C&C[/b], but this here? It took every single [b]C&C[/b] element and flushed 'em down the toilet. Resource gathering? Believe it or not, it's no more. Remember the days we were arguing about [b]Generals[/b] having resource management similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] instead of our usual [b]Dune II[/b] thing? Well, resources are no more. No resources – no problem by [b]EA[/b] logic. Technically, [b]Tiberium[/b] ([b]C&C[/b]'s counterpart of [b]Spice[/b]) is still here, but it's just some crystals you'll be able to pick up now and then to upgrade units. Like I said, resource gathering? Not a thing. And so is a base building. Again, remember that old argument about how in [b]Generals[/b] we were able to build anywhere (similar to [b]WarCraft[/b] too), while “real” [b]C&C[/b] was all about the construction yard and things we were building around it? In this game we can't build at all. Well, technically, there [i]is[/i] one building. And the whole game revolves around it.

Everybody who played [b]C&C[/b] is familiar with the [b]MCV[/b]. So-called mobile construction vehicle was pretty much a portable construction yard. The original idea was to let us choose place for our new base to get the advantage we wanted. Now? Now it's more like our portable all-in-one base. Not only we can move it at any time ([b]StarCraft[/b] anyone?), it also acts like all other buildings from previous games. We build units, we purchase upgrades, we use powers... You've got the idea. Our whole base is just that – one fat [b]MCV[/b]. Where do we get money to produce units, you may ask? Well, that's a very good question, because in this game? You don't need money. You're free to build as many units as you want. There's a very strict population limit now, though, much more strict than in those [b]BLIZZARD[/b] titles. But that's just a thing. Forget about those big armies. Our goal in this game is, while only having a few units, to figure out perfect combination to outsmart our enemy.

But OK, you may say that simplified take on [b]Company of Heroes[/b], while not being a [b]C&C[/b] at all, may still be a good game. True. And that's where our second problem comes in. See, [b]C&C4[/b] is not a well-made product. Not even thought-through. The first thing you'll notice after the initial shock is... how hard this game is. Which... isn't even true. The problem is – single player campaign here is tied to your online profile. Remember the challenges from [b]RA3[/b] expansion? The ones, where you started with close to no technologies (units)? That's the stuff. You start single player campaign with nothing. Yet doing some skirmish grinding first will make it much easier. And a lot of grinding? You guessed it, there are no limits. Grind for the highest commander level (may take quite some time, especially since [b]GDI[/b] and [b]Nod[/b] are leveled separately) and get big advantage for your single player experience. What. The f*ck? Pretty sure single player experience implies dealing with properly calculated conditions. Here? It's a lot like playing story in some MMO. You stuck? Go grind somewhere else and come back later. Like I said, WTF?

Thankfully, most likely, you won't even get a chance to suffer through all that. Why? *SIGH* Did you play [b]Anthem[/b], guys? [b]C&C4[/b] was exactly that long before it. Starting [b]C&C4[/b] goes like this – launch the game, enter login and password for your [b]EA[/b] account, get an error, change password to fit eight symbols (don't ask me why) and voilà! The game works. Is it, though? Right after launch you'll be asked to enter login and password [i]again[/i]. Only this time even the short password won't help. Why? Because you need to have [b]EA[/b] app running on background. Again, don't ask me why (it doesn't look like the game interacts with it). Even after all that, there's still a chance for a game to tell you to go f*ck yourself. Hello, [b]Anthem[/b]. How you doin'?

So here we are. Not only this game dropped everything that we fell in love back in 1992, it also feels rushed (naturally, it's buggy and imbalanced too) and, well, it's half-broken. And it's all pretty sad, you know? The atmosphere here is quite solid. Moreover, the story is quite creative. It has FMV cutscenes, it's told from the first-person perspective and we, the commander, are the main character. The one who plays the most important role. Sure, it's too short (game only has seven missions per faction), but still, with some proper gameplay, it'll be quite enjoyable. Unfortunately, [b]C&C4[/b] is a mixture of the unfortunate coincidences and bad decisions. When you look back, you see that such a mistake was inevitable. But it [i]is[/i] [b]EA[/b]'s fault that shot ended up being deadly. Dixi.

column8:
It's not just a bad C&C game, it's a bad RTS. It's fascinating how it exists and nobody at any point didn't halt further development. It doesn't feature base building, something C&C is iconic for, but instead features a "Command Unit" which, by itself, is actually a cool idea but in execution for this game is dreadful. The game series is infamous for spam, it's often known as "Spam & Conquer" for whoever spams the most MBTs first wins. This game not only amplifies that, it limits you from doing much of anything else. 


The unit design is strange too. It feels like a mod more than a sensible professional game studio, but it also feels like a mobile game more than a computer game made by a game studio. The campaign constantly ruins lore and immersion. To this day, what lives rent free in my head is the mission where you need to save x amount of busses the GDI is trying to slaughter. You could literally sit there, turtle, and watch thousands of busses be destroyed for an infant amount spawn and drive, you just need to save X amount for a mission success.  I don't know how anyone can play the game without losing any little immersion they have by such low thought out "video-gamey" moments. 

Speaking of lore, spoilers! Not that you should play this game,,,, 
[spoiler] You also assassinate Kane at the end of the GDI campaign with a sniper. Nothing crazy to elaborate,  just they decided he is super special and requires a super special bullet to kill him. No, no biblical references to Cane. No, no references to cloning. No, no references to anything that made C&C special and Kane special, no interesting reveal, just "he's just super special because he's around the Tiberium so much". It's just better to leave mysteries alone, they didn't need to answer this mystery, and they answered it so lazily and boring.
[/spoiler]

Overall, game is terrible. Don't play it. It killed the series. It killed it so badly that all we get are slop mobile games now.

column8:
UA

Остання частина легендарної серії ігор, і цей факт робить усе моє та й більшості фанатів всесвіту Command & Conquer ще більш засмученими та кислими від досвіду проходження. Я й не буду дивуватися, що EA спеціально поховали надію на продовження у майбутньому та продовжили доїти більш прибуткові франшизи.

Почну зі сюжету. C&C не славилася своїми історіями та персонажами, але все одно вони привертали нашу увагу й нам було цікаво стежити за подальшими діями. Четвірка не дає ніякого чіткого розвитку всесвіту тіберія. Персонажі сірі та не відокремлюються від одне одного, навіть Кейн не може скерувати цю всю мішанину у правильне русло. Відсутні деталі та загально обізнані межі історії від завершення попередньої гри Kane's Wrath. Дані також не повернулися. А про скріннів взагалі мовчу - їх просто немає(тільки згадки), хоча величезний натяк на їх повернення був продемонстрований у кінці їхньої кампанії. 

Геймплей перетворився фундаментально й сам факт цього розізлив багатьох гравців, але на мою особисту думку проблема не в цьому, а в реалізації, Кульгає динаміка гри та гейм-дизайн місій разом зі картами й режимами звичайних матчей(а режим є тільки один - контроль точок). Не відчувається міць усіх юнітів та будівель, навіть бойові одиниці останього, третього рівня не показують страх на полі бою. Апогеєм розчарування стали культові робот "Аватар" та танк "Мамонт". Деякі війська мені здаються зовсім марними та не розумію нащо вони були створені(як сеймснік НОД) Присутність очків командування значно обмежує гравця та свідомо робить гру менш бажаною. Завдання, які нам даються впродовж проходження по сюжету, малоцікаві, а додаткові взагалі мають практично ніякого сенсу свого існування. Єдине необов'язкове доручення, яке було гідним виконання - це рятування полонених у місії. де ми ловимо Гідеона("Нагорода за єресь"), а найцікавіше - вбивство снайпера("Стікаючи кров'ю").

Графіка приємна та не розчаровує, а дизайн юнітів є навіть іноді креативними. Саундтрек - єдина частина гри, яку можна та треба хвалити. Композитори не робили свою працю, плюючи на кінцевий результат.

У підсумку я скажу лише одне - мене поглинає смуток за цей фінал. Ставлю 4 з 10.

EN

The last part of the legendary game series, and this fact makes me and most of the fans of Command & Conquer universe even more upset and sour from the experience of playing it. I will not be surprised that EA deliberately buried the hope for next part in the future in order to continue milking more profitable franchises.

Let's start with the plot. C&C was not famous for its stories and characters, but still they attracted our attention and we were interested in following further actions. The fourth one does not give any clear development of the Tiberium universe. The characters are gray and are inseparable from each other, even Kane cannot direct this whole mess that is plot into the right direction. There are no details and well-known plot points of the story from the end of the previous game - Kane's Wrath. Data also did not return. And I won't say anything about the Scrin - they are simply not there (only mentioned), although a huge hint of their return was demonstrated at the end of their campaign.

The gameplay has changed fundamentally and the very fact has angered many players, but in my personal opinion the problem is not in this, but in the implementation. The dynamics of the game and the game design of the missions are lame, along with the maps and gamemodes of regular skirmishes (and there is only one  - point control). The might of all units and buildings is not felt, even the combat troops of the last, third level do not show fear on the battlefield. The apogee of disappointment were the iconic robot "Avatar" and the tank "Mammoth". Some seem completely useless to me and I do not understand why they were created (like NOD's aftershock). The presence of command points significantly limits the player and deliberately makes the game less desirable. The tasks that are given to us during the walkthrough are of little interest, and the additional ones generally have practically no meaning of their existence. The only optional ones that were worthy of completion are rescue of prisoners in the mission. where we try to catch Gideon ("Heresy's Award"), and the most interesting one is where we kill the sniper ("Bleed Out").

The graphics are nice and do not disappoint, and the unit designs are creative, sometimes. The soundtrack is the only part of the game that can and must be praised. The composers did care about the end result.

In the end, I will say only one thing - I am consumed by sorrow because of this end. I give it 4 out of 10.
It's not the greatest game the older ones are better but it's playable

column8:
Recommended to those who are not familiar with any other games of Command & Conquer franchise.

IMHO the game could have much better reception if it was not released as part of C&C Tiberium franchise. 
The gameplay concept is completely changed from classical resource gathering and base building to managing the mobile factories of 3 types (air, vehicles or infantry units production + their support). 
A worthy parts of the game are soundrack and list of units. All other things are worse comparing to previous games of the serie.
Too bad the achievements are not integrated to Steam.
Due to bad reception it is no surprise if multiplayer mode is wasted, sucks, etc.

Ich bin wirklich sehr eintäuscht vom Command & Conquer™ 4 Tiberian Twilight.
Alleine dieser hick kack mit der Anmeldung ist eine Katastrophe. Das Spiel startet erst gar nicht,  wenn man es sich von Steam aus Installiert. Also habe ich es wieder Deinstalliert und über die EA App erneut installiert. Aber wenn man glaubt es startet nun ist leider Fehl am Platz. Die EA-App muss geöffnet sein und von dort aus muss man das spiel einmal starten und auf die Fehlermeldung warten von der EA App. Fehler schließen und das Spiel über den Desktop starten. Nun geht auch der Login warum auch immer ... Im Spiel endlich angekommen man denkt Cool ich kann zocken hehe nee wäre ja zu schön.
Mann muss erstmal alles einstellen Grtafig usw. ist das geschafft kann es endlich los gehen. Wenn mann aber denkt es ist wie C&C 3 wird leider auch sehr eintäuscht. Das ganze Spielprinzipien mit diesen sogenannten Croller ist mal sowas von blöd man hat Offensiv, defensiv  und Support. will man zwischen diesen wechseln muss man den zu vorgebauten Croller immer zerstören. Da diese alle Gebäude in einen vereinen. Man hat keine Kraftwerke mehr oder Fahrzeugfabriken  einfach nichts. Man ist beschränkt was die Einheiten angeht usw. C&C Scharm ade ! 

Ich weis nicht was sie EA dabei gedacht hat. Aber ich kann das Spiel nicht empfehlen
column9:
I'm really disappointed with Command & Conquer™ 4 Tiberian Twilight.
This hassle with the login alone is a disaster. The game doesn't even start when you install it from Steam. So I uninstalled it and reinstalled it via the EA app. But when you think it's starting, it's unfortunately not working. The EA app has to be open, and from there you have to launch the game once and wait for the error message from the EA app. Close the error and start the game from the desktop. Now you can log in, for whatever reason... Finally getting into the game, you think, "Cool, I can play, hehe, no, that would be too good."
You have to set everything up first, etc. Once you've done that, you can finally get started. But if you think it's like C&C 3, you're unfortunately very disappointed. The whole gameplay with these so-called scrollers is so stupid: you have offense, defense, and support. If you want to switch between them, you always have to destroy the pre-built scroller. Because they combine all the buildings into one. You no longer have power plants or vehicle factories. You're limited in terms of units, etc. Goodbye C&C charm!

I don't know what EA was thinking. But I can't recommend the game.

column8: This game is a very fun and original for its time C&C series spin-off wrongly calculated and advertised many years ago as 4th main title. You doesn't build Your base, You doesn't harvest resources, instead You'll got three types of the MCV to choose from, each with different unit types available to produce and for the rest of the time trying to combine and micro Your few units (cause of the pop cap never seen in any C&C before - excluding Sole Survivor) with or without friends to take over certain buildings around the map. These places generate points You'll need to collect to win the game. Destroying enemy forces will give You the points too. One game could take even few hours. Sounds boring but its not, especially when You must level up both GDI and NOD to get better units and upgrades. It weirdly reminds me of Halo Wars, but slower paced. Honestly speaking this title is really worth Your time while waiting for real fourth main C&C game. Or maybe idk 8th if EA still can't count properly.

column8:
How to bypass the EA bug to play C&C 4 Tiberian Twillight (Fixed) and successfully launched the game.

1) Right click the game in your library and select browse local files.

2) Find the application (.exe) file CNC4, right click and select properties. Under Compatibility, make sure that Run this program as administrator is checked, and apply.

3) Make sure that your EA.com password is 8 characters  also that make sure it does not have 
ANY SPECIAL CHARACTERS IN IT [!@#$%^&*].

Noted: This game will not work if there are more than 8 characters in your passwords.

4) Bingo, The game should work and you can see for yourself why so many people who have gotten it to work still hate it.

column8:
Eigentlich schon ein würdiger Nachfolger! 
Also wenns denn dann doch mal läuft wies soll...
Habe die komplette Reihe für 6 Euro bekommen und bin gespannt ob mich bei allen Spielen die gleichen Probleme mit dem Passwort erwarten... einfach nur nervig!
Die Missionen sind bisher (8 Stunden) sehr abswechslungsreich und mir offenbaren sich immer neue Taktiken.
Grafisch sehr gut gelungen und die Maps machen Lust zu erkunden statt direkt den Feind platt zu machen und weiter gehts - Das lässt der dauernde Zeitdruck aber irgendwie nicht so wirklich zu. 
Wer normalerweise riesige Armeen in die Schlacht schickt hat noch einen Grund zum umdenken denn die kriegt man einfach nicht zusammen.
An die guten alten Zeiten mit "Generals" wird es definitiv nicht anknüpfen können aber die Story zocken is Pflicht.
Das Spiel könnte noch sehr lange nach der Weihnachtszeit Freude bereiten... wenns denn startet XD
column9:
Actually, it's a worthy successor!

Well, if it finally works out as it should...
I got the complete series for 6 euros and I'm curious to see if I'll have the same password problems with all the games... just annoying!

The missions so far (8 hours) have been very varied, and new tactics keep revealing themselves to me.

Graphically, they're very well done, and the maps make you want to explore instead of just annihilating the enemy and moving on - but the constant time pressure somehow doesn't really allow for that.

If you normally send huge armies into battle, you have another reason to rethink things, because you just can't get them together.

It definitely won't be able to emulate the good old days of "Generals," but playing the story is a must.

The game could provide enjoyment long after the Christmas season... if it ever launches. XD

column8:
7.4小时通关，最具潜力的一部CNC，它不是烂作，但可惜它叫《命令与征服》！

终于知道为什么这代要叫王八战争了
第一点，GDI和nod的MCV移动起来确实挺像一个乌龟的，移动贼慢，而且陆行MCV还有四条腿
第二点，这代的战役需要经常换家换地点，甚至你有三种类型的MCV，属于乌龟换壳了
第三点，这代战役经常需要你那MCV充当人肉护盾，因为这代MCV实在太硬了，硬的就像乌龟

移动速度，坚硬程度，作息规律，还真就是个王八

如果不叫《命令与征服》的话，设计的其实挺有创意和点子的，跟前作无脑堆兵冲点不同，这代你需要占领各种据点，据点可以为你提供火力掩护，你需要经常的去占领对面的据点，然后把自己的MCV开过去驻扎在那从而做到自己的领地向前推进的效果，因为这代没有资源采集玩法，而且单位有数量限制，你只需要专注于指定推进计划，如何占领地盘并把自己的MCV向前推进就行

也是因为这点，游戏节奏真的被拖沓死了，在前作你可以做一个囤囤鼠，在攒够一大波兵力后猛冲对面老家非常有爽点，而这代因为单位限制和玩法思路的转变导致传统的CNC爽点荡然无存，值得一提的是这代的满编轰炸机依然很带劲，推起单位来效率依然很高

总的来说这是一部不那么传统的CNC，如果它不叫《命令与征服》我或许会对这款游戏有较高的评价，但很可惜本作的一些转变让它玩起来不是那么“传统”，其核心爽点也应设计思路的转变而丢失，很可惜它叫CNC！
column9:
7.4 hours to beat. This is the most promising C&C game. It's not a bad game, but it's just a shame it's called "Command & Conquer"!

I finally understand why this game is called "Turtle Wars."
First, GDI and NOD's MCVs move like turtles—very slowly, and the land-based MCVs have four legs.
Second, this campaign requires frequent relocations. You even have three types of MCVs, like a turtle changing its shell.
Third, this campaign often requires your MCV to act as a human shield because it's incredibly tough, like a turtle.

The speed, toughness, and regularity—it's truly a turtle.

If it weren't called "Command & Conquer," the design would actually be quite creative and ingenious. Unlike the previous game's mindless troop-heavy rush, this game requires you to capture various strongholds, which provide cover fire. You need to frequently capture enemy strongholds and then station your MCV there to advance your territory. The effectiveness of the push is quite different. Because this game lacks resource gathering and has a limited number of units, you simply focus on a specific push plan, capturing territory, and pushing your MCV forward.

This also makes the game's pacing feel incredibly slow. In the previous game, you could be a hoarder, amassing a large wave of troops and charging into the enemy stronghold, which was incredibly satisfying. However, this game's unit restrictions and shift in gameplay philosophy have completely eliminated the traditional CNC thrill. It's worth noting that a full complement of bombers is still very powerful, and pushing units is still very efficient.

Overall, this is a less traditional CNC game. If it weren't called "Command & Conquer," I might have given it a higher rating, but unfortunately, the changes made this game feel less "traditional," and its core thrill has been lost due to the shift in design. It's a shame it's called CNC!

column8: If you do play this create a new account and use an 8 letter and number password, nothing else will work. Do not use your main EA account as this is a security risk to your account .
column9: If you do play this create a new account and use an 8 letter and number password, nothing else will work. Do not use your main EA account as this is a security risk to your account .

This episode's plot is completely unreliable. In the first few episodes of C&C, Ken was quite charismatic. Besides the look and name, this episode makes me wonder if you're Ken's brother. Why are your personalities so different?

Each time I enter the game, I have to log in to my EA account twice. Sometimes, it says "error" or "wrong password" when I log in (even though it's not wrong). I have to log in multiple times before I can even connect and enter the game. But I only play the single-player campaign, and the constant login requests are really annoying.

The gameplay is also terrible. Like Red Dead Redemption 3, it inherits the "General" bug, and it also has a commander advancement system. Not the "General" kind, but more like an online/mobile game. Your account has rank upgrades, and there's one for GDI and one for NOD. You level up faster by unlocking more in-game achievements.

While you don't need to collect resources to recruit soldiers, the recruitment limit is 50-60 units. However, each type of soldier takes up a different number of units, so you might only have ten soldiers in a game before you can't recruit any more. Playing real-time strategy like this is truly...
The game collects resources in each battle to unlock your own commander abilities...
If you're tempted to play the campaign from the start with a horde of enemy troops, NOD enemies constantly occupying your machines, and mission objectives, you'll be told to wait until you've upgraded your commander level...

column8: Like every one else has said EA did a wonderful job screwing this game up. Getting into the game is an ordeal by itself, no base building or resource gathering. column8:
It sucks. Technical issues with the always online requirements aside, it isn't fun to play. No base building, no resource gathering, pathetically limited unit cap, units are overall uninteresting, the game play is uninteresting, the story makes no sense, the cut scenes all look like a youtuber made them, and all this pretends to be a mainline command and conquer game. It was so bad that EA pretty much killed the franchise after this disaster. I wouldn't even consider anything in this canon. This game is at best a spin off that had some story super glued onto it at the last minute, as it was originally developed as a mobile game. EA sucks as a company and ruined my favorite franchise in history and this game just bleeds that out of every crevice. 

F*ck EA for making this garbage and I hope against hope no one buys this.

column8: I decided to give this game a chance despite my reservations, but it turned out to be a huge disappointment. It doesn’t play like the rest of the series at all. Instead of the strategic depth I expected, there’s just one mech, no base-building, and no resource gathering. The units felt awkward and unpolished—far from what I hoped for in the fourth main installment. They had so much material to build on from the rest of the series but failed to adapt anything meaningful. Overall, it’s just a terrible game.

column8:
TLDR: Disgusting 'recreation' of the best RTS series of all time; marred by stupid double-logins

Pros:
- None

Cons;
- Requires you to change your EA login password to 8 characters in length with 1 uppercase character.  
- Requires you to login twice just to reach the main menu
- Completely destroys everything that made the original games fun; primarily, base-building.  

I regret installing this trash

column9:
At first, I was puzzled by how such a classic game could have so many negative reviews.
After playing it for a bit... Alas, it's a patchwork of oddities. It's neither StarCraft nor Warcraft, and it's tainted my impression of Command & Conquer.

column8: The game that killed the Command and Conquer series. I so badly want to like this game because it has many of the classic units you remember from past C&C games. The issue is that this game tried to reinvent the franchise by getting rid of everything that made the series great. Base building is replaced with crawlers that act as like a mobile unit that can create more units. The amount of units that you can create is minuscule, the campaign is short and boring, multiplayer no longer exists and there is no skirmish mode. There is no reason to buy this game as all you have access to is campaign, and that's after jumping through hoops to get the game to boot. This game is included in the C&C collection on steam, and that's the only reason anyone should get this game. Even after you get it, I still don't recommend trying it unless you must know why we don't get Command and Conquer games anymore.

column8: When I launch this game, I am greeted to a login screen asking me for my EA account information. I do not have an EA account. I bought this game on Steam, not Origin or anywhere else. If I hadn't bought this game as part of a bundle, I would have immediately returned it. I left the login screen open more than 5 minutes so that I could write this review. Do not buy this game unless you have an EA account. You must be online to play this game, even in single player.

column9: I couldn't even get into this game properly. I bought it way back when, as a bundle. I wanted to play it just for company, because I love this series. EA—you used to release awesome games, but for this piece of code that was rewritten five times, you'll burn in hell for five years.

column8:
首先最大的问题就是能不能运行，除此以外，其他方面也不尽人意。

作为cnc系列官方所搞出来的正传，违背祖宗之法打改游戏玩法，取消了建筑系统，经济系统，加入了人口限制（大概是工t1步兵3，t1单位6，t3大型单位12，总人口50），让系列本来宏大的战斗场景不复存在。剧情更是逆天中的逆天。本来好端端的科技树硬是拆成3份（进攻型，防守型，支援型），让单人基本上很难达成步坦协同，陆空协同。然后作为结局作，最后决战更是一点感觉没做出来。

即使抛开cnc这个系列印象也是一坨，作为一个rts游戏居然单位靠指挥官等级解锁，而且gdi和nod等级分开算。初始只有t1的低级单位，战斗力低不说属性克制都凑不出来，本来以为对战里拿着t1单位去和t2t3打以及非常逆天了，结果连过战役的单位都要靠等级解锁，没有等级非常难办。（不过也不算特别难办，因为就连最后一关都能锁科技上限为t1）

不过单位的外形还是不错，为各种mod提供灵感思路，也算是为数不多的贡献吧。
column9:
The biggest issue is whether it runs. Beyond that, other aspects are also unsatisfactory.

As the official sequel to the CNC series, it defies traditional gameplay conventions by removing the building and economic systems and introducing population limits (roughly 3 Tier 1 infantry, 6 Tier 1 units, 12 Tier 3 large units, for a total population of 50), completely destroying the series' typically grand battle scenes. The plot is even more absurd. The previously well-organized tech tree is forcibly split into three parts (offensive, defensive, and support), making it virtually impossible for a single player to achieve coordinated infantry, tanks, or land and air forces. Furthermore, as the finale, the final battle feels completely unrealistic.

Even putting aside the CNC series itself, the impression it leaves is still a mess. For an RTS game, units are unlocked based on commander level, and the levels for GDI and NOD are calculated separately. Initially, there were only low-level tier 1 units. Not only were their combat power low, but they also lacked any stat counters. I thought using tier 1 units against tier 2 and tier 3 units would be incredibly powerful, but it turns out even the units needed to pass the campaign must be unlocked by level, making it incredibly difficult without them. (Though it's not particularly difficult, since even the final stage locks the tech cap at tier 1.)

The units' aesthetics are still quite nice, though, and they've provided inspiration for various mods, which is one of their few contributions.

column8: Even in single player I need to create an account and log on to some lame EA games BS, where the servers doesn't work. After 3-4 hours of googeling and solving different problems, I got to the point where it said I needed to change to a shorter password, and the redit or whatever said I needed to make a 6 digit password to make it work, however EA games require you to have a 8 digit password. The game itself might be the worst in the series, so many of the fundamentals are thrown out the window, and the "new" take on the mechanics I loved in the series are at best sub par. My main problem is that the MCV respawns, so you can not really win like you would in EVERY OTHER C&C game ever. The whole Tiberium thing is just trash, as you will not mine ore like in the old games, and there is no power and almost no building. Just mindless grinding to unlock generic units that seems loosly based on old artwork, but nothing really cool, and all the best cool stuff like missing. Yes, and the ingame clock doesn't really seems to work in like the time we use on this planet, like 10 minutes remaining is somehow way longer than 15 minutes on a real clock. I just play solo skrimish tho', so your experience may vary, if you somehow are able to even get to the menu of this sad end to such an amazing series. I think RA2 is the best, but I still enjoy RA3 alot for context.

column8:
Bonjour cher joueur de C&C

How to run C&C 4 tuto, for english people who want to play convert this following text in english: 

Je sais que beaucoup d'entre vous n'arrive pas à jouer à ce jeux, mais je suis là pour vous aider, c'est le C&C qui à encore des serveurs actif sans mode qui marche alors suivez ce petit "tuto" pour jouer au jeu.

Premiére chose importante, votre mot de passe du compte EA doit faire moins de 16 caractères. Le jeu est vieux et il faut vous authentifier dans le jeu et l'encadré qui contient ce mot de passe ne peux pas accueillir plus de 16 lettres (ne vous inquiétez pas pour votre @mail la c'est bon)

Deuxiéme chose si vous avez votre mot de passe qui est bon et que votre jeu vous affiche "Erreur de sytéme générale" ou un truc comme ça, réessayer  en faisant une erreur de mot de passe exprés: par exemple votre mot passe est "truc1234" le jeu affiche "Erreur du systéme générale" vous marquez a la place "trcu5555" il vous dit "Mauvais mot de passe ou nom de compte" et remettez votre mot de passe. Si ça ne marche toujours pas réessayer plusieurs fois en redémarant le jeu.

Voilà normalement ça marche, si vous voulez me poser des questions envoyer en MP je repondrais.

Bonne chance mes amis et donnons à cette licence la gloire qu'elle mérite parce que putain de merde EA de con de pire d'entreprise
column9:
Hello dear C&C player

How to run C&C 4 tutorial, for English people who want to play convert this following text into English:

I know many of you can't play this game, but I'm here to help you. This is the C&C that still has active servers without a working mode, so follow this little tutorial to play the game.

First important thing: your EA account password must be less than 16 characters. The game is old and you have to authenticate yourself in the game, and the box containing this password can't hold more than 16 letters (don't worry about your @email, it's fine).

Second thing: if your password is correct and your game displays "General System Error" or something like that, try again by deliberately entering the wrong password: for example, if your password is "truc1234," the game displays "General System Error." Enter "trcu5555" instead. It tells you "Wrong password or account name" and enter your password again. If it still doesn't work, try again several times by restarting the game.

That's it, it should work. If you have any questions, send me a PM, and I'll answer.

Good luck, my friends, and let's give this franchise the glory it deserves because, damn it, EA, the worst idiot of a company.

I am almost lucky. Obviously I've heard the stories, I've seen gameplay online. Its honestly even a mistake to call it a Command and Conquer game. But it came bundled with the actually good CNC games so I bought it for what steam tells me was £0.94.

I'm not messing with keys and re registrations. Even if I did, you would have to log in with ea email and password, twice, every single time it loaded, for a game no one even wants to play. 

Don't bother, its another one of God's Mistakes.

column8:
Saying C&C 4 is subpar is not news to longtime C&C fans, but after over a decade of pretending this game did not exist, I finally tried it. Why did I do it? A mix of nostalgia, completionism and a dose of curiosity.
I can now honestly say this game deserves every part of its awful reputation.
Even getting the game running is tricky and I will link a guide in this review if by any chance you want to try it for yourself.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3198390063
Once you actually get it working you will be forced to log in not once but twice every time you launch the game, which will always be connected to the internet. I guess EA was worried that some people would pirate this masterpiece.

 When you actually start playing you will see that the gameplay does not resemble a C&C game whatsoever. No real base building or resource gathering. What do you think this is a C&C game or something? Well, it really does not feel like one at all. When I found out that this was originally an online only game made for the Asian market, which had a story attached to it to sell more copies during production. It all made more sense.
This brings me to the next point.

But Vogel, besides the gameplay C&C always had a fun story, Full motion video cutscenes, are those any good? The answer to that question my friends is a solid negative. The story feels like some lazy fanfiction that you would find on the internet. The cutscenes obviously have much lower production values compared to Tiberian Sun and C&C 3. Here is a good visual example of what I mean when I speak of lower production values.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=522954423

As I was watching these cutscenes I was wondering if Joseph Kucan (Kane) was thinking about the good old days when this franchise would feature Hollywood actors like Michael Ironside, J.K. Simmons, James Earl Jones, Billy Dee Williams and Ray Wise. I can't say I have heard of any of the actors who were cast for C&C 4 and frankly besides Joe Kucan,  most of them were not very memorable in this game. 
I like Joseph Kucan as an actor and I was always surprised that he did not have more roles in Hollywood movies, he would have been great as a villain in a James Bond movie during the Pierce Brosnan era, but I digress. It is just a shame that C&C 4 was the sendoff that a character as iconic in PC gaming as Kane and the C&C franchise got.

Some people would bring up the music as an example of something  good about this game but honestly, I thought it was trying too hard to sound "epic" and after a few hours of play I just wanted to turn it off. Especially the Nod soundtrack. Give me Frank Klepacki’s soundtrack for C&C 95 over this games soundtrack any day. Tracks like “Act on Instinct”, Remember the track that kicked off the whole C&C series? :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n4AUY-v1nsE


Seriously unless you are a completionist like me and feel the need to play every C&C game, just avoid C&C 4 like a blue Tiberian field during an ion storm.

Also the game's updated graphics and improved gameplay mechanics with  new GDI and Nod factions bring fresh and exciting gameplay mechanics.

column8:
除了音乐好听之外，这游戏真的是一无是处！游戏的机制设计真是让人匪夷所思，这还是命令与征服吗？玩法完全变味，且人口限制又是什么鬼？战略游戏的魅力在于调配和指挥大军。
且单人战役剧情发展得草草了事，让人感觉就像是在赶工作，不负责任地把故事随便收尾。就这么完了？这一作完全不配称为CNC系列的一部分，让无数老玩家失望至极的游戏。
column9:
Aside from the great music, this game is completely worthless! The game's mechanics are incredibly confusing. Is this still Command & Conquer? The gameplay is completely distorted, and what the hell is the population limit? The charm of strategy games lies in commanding and managing armies.
The single-player campaign is also rushed through, feeling like a rushed, irresponsible ending. Is that the end? This game is completely unworthy of being part of the Command & Conquer series, and it has left countless veteran players deeply disappointed.

column8:
Command & Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight is such a misunderstood gem, I think it honestly gets way too much flak from the community. Sure, it’s a departure from the classic C&C formula, but isn’t that what makes it unique? They ditched base-building and resource-gathering—yeah, it was bold—but the new Crawler system adds a fresh dynamic that keeps the gameplay moving. Instead of turtling in a base, you're constantly on the move, which makes things feel more tactical and tense. This constant forward momentum really changes the strategy in interesting ways, especially with the three distinct unit types: Offense, Defense, and Support. It really makes every battle feel different depending on which role you take on.

The story? Classic C&C drama. Kane’s back, GDI and Nod are still at each other’s throats, and there’s this whole apocalyptic vibe with Tiberium threatening to destroy Earth. I mean, it’s the end of the Tiberium saga! Sure, the cutscenes have less of that campy charm we loved from earlier games, but they still hit the mark for me. The narrative is darker, but fittingly so for a series finale.

As for the visuals, they might not pop as much as Red Alert 3, but come on, it’s still solid for a 2010 game. The unit designs are cool, especially the upgraded Nod Avatar walkers. People complain about the graphics, but hey, that’s hardly the point of a strategy game, right? It’s about the gameplay and that’s where C&C 4 shines in its own way.

Okay, I know the game has its quirks—logging in every time is annoying (especially when there are technical issues), and sure, the campaign can be a grind if you're not into the whole "leveling up to unlock better units" thing. But if you're patient, it’s totally worth it. The multiplayer and co-op are where this game thrives, offering some seriously fun moments once you get the hang of things.

All in all, Tiberian Twilight isn’t perfect, but it’s definitely not the trainwreck people make it out to be. If you’re a die-hard C&C fan, give it a shot with an open mind. It’s different, but that’s not necessarily a bad thing! It’s a refreshing twist on the formula and a great way to end a legendary saga.

column8:
Considering i got this with EA play, its not that bad..  tiny cost for a game to play.
  
That being said..  compared to all other C&C games, this is trash, online only is a major pain, im having to login again and again with errors, i do eventually get in to play. the whole login to launch, then login again to play.. like seriously lol who thought that was a good idea, never seen that on a game before, major flaw.  

the game itself is such a downgrade from previous C&C games, i always loved to build my base and get the army out, play strategic..  cant really do that in this game.  most missions are done in less than 10mins, the division of  types.. defensive has troops and towers with a power supply, offence has vehicles, support has air units and ability points.
you cant really mix and match them

as a lover of all C&C games, i had to play it and i will finish the campaign at least.
If another ever comes out or is in design phase.. i hope they go back to the real C&C style and dont repeat this tragic mistake of a game.

column8:
提升级别，迎接泰伯利亚传奇的史诗结局
精辟，实在精辟
提升级别——不升级你啥像样的东西都玩不到
泰伯利亚的史诗结局——直接一作把一个传奇RTS系列给埋了
------------------------------------
剧情怎么样暂且不谈。[spoiler] 给GDI打工，转正后就立刻死了老婆 [/spoiler]
只说遭遇战部分，取消掉经济运营和对抗，直接塔塔开和占点，然后通过强单位克制让玩家进行微操和调整部队编成，这套设计思路其实还挺有意思的。
但是将单位和升级解锁与等级直接挂钩的失败的逼肝机制真的毁了一切体验。等级不高你只能海低级兵造低级建筑，升级也没啥可点的东西，你的游戏体验是严重残疾的——劝退效果满分。
战役部分你能使用的单位同样跟这个等级系统绑定，而且制作组还自作聪明地加入了获取经验限制······进一步劝退。
所以对于想找个RTS游戏正常玩玩的玩家来说，本作不值得购买。如果你是想收集齐CNC系列、出于猎奇心态、打包买或者喜加一的话，倒是可以入一下——毕竟这游戏还能正常的启动和玩嘛（虽然不是每一次）
column9:
Level up and welcome the epic conclusion of the Tiberium saga.
Brilliant, truly brilliant.
Level up—you won't get anything decent without leveling up.
Tiberium's epic conclusion—a single game completely buries a legendary RTS series.
------------------------------------
Let's not talk about the plot for now. [spoiler] I worked for GDI, and my wife died immediately after getting hired. [/spoiler]
Just talking about the skirmishes: eliminating economic management and confrontation, focusing solely on tower defense and point capture. Then, through strong unit counters, players can micromanage and adjust their troop composition. This design concept is actually quite interesting.

However, the failed grind-forcing mechanic that directly ties unit and upgrade unlocks to level really ruins the experience. If you're not at a high level, you can only use low-level troops and build low-level buildings, and there's nothing to upgrade. Your gaming experience is severely crippled—a complete turn-off.

The units you can use in the campaign are also tied to this level system, and the team even cleverly added experience gain restrictions... further discouraging you from playing. So for players who are looking for an RTS game to play normally, this game is not worth buying. If you want to collect the CNC series, buy it for curiosity, buy it in a package, or buy it as a bonus, you can buy it - after all, this game can still be started and played normally (although not every time).

La saga es buenísima pero este ultimo lanzamiento es una tremenda cagada, los red alert 3 son muchísimo mejor que este pedazo de MARRÓN, hasta me atrevo a decir que los comand & conquer generals es mucho mejor que este juego, venían re bien con la saga y la re cagaron con este ultimo lanzamiento. No se por que tuvieron la idea de innovar una nueva mecánica y para colmo gráficos menos que los red alert 3, no se siente satisfactorio en nada. Agradezcan que lo jugué mas de 1 hora por que la verdad no lo pensaba jugar, le había dado una oportunidad por respeto a la saga pero ni eso! no puedo! me mata! me saca años de vida este juego. 

Dentro de todo y perdón por mi vocabulario anterior pero se lo merecen por que le erraron bastante, almenos que hagan otro comand & conquer red alert 4 y bien hecho o que el 5 por favor logre tapar lo que el 4 no pudo brindar. Aun confió que sacaran otro red alert que tanto esperamos!
column9:
The series is great, but this latest release is a huge piece of shit. Red Alert 3 is way better than this piece of BROWN. I even dare say that Command & Conquer Generals is way better than this game. They were really good with the series, but they really screwed up with this latest release. I don't know why they had the idea of ​​innovating a new mechanic, and to top it off, the graphics are worse than Red Alert 3's; it doesn't feel satisfying at all. Be thankful that I played it for over an hour because I honestly wasn't going to play it. I had given it a chance out of respect for the series, but not even that! I can't! It kills me! This game takes years off my life.

All in all, and sorry for my previous vocabulary, but they deserve it because they missed quite a bit. At least make another Command & Conquer Red Alert 4 and do it properly, or maybe 5 can please cover up what 4 couldn't offer. I still hope they release another Red Alert, which we're waiting for!

column8:
I bought C&C4 when it first came out. I hated it back then and I thought MAYBE if I installed it now I would appreciate it a bit more. So I wrote this review...
This game is an abomination, a black hole of fun where joy goes to die. Imagine all the worst parts of every Command and Conquer game, mix them together, and then set it on fire. That smoldering, glitch-ridden trash fire would be miles better than this "game."

First off, how did the cut scenes go down in quality fro C&C3? I know the cut scenes were never anything better than a subpar B rated movie, but these are poorly designed even by Westwood standards. The first cut scene was a pair of blocky fighter over a poorly rendered city. Good start. Kane walks down a halway with nothing in his hands of in his coat, then pulls a basketball sized Teseract out of his pocket. From where?

The gameplay? Calling it "gameplay" is a stretch. It’s more like a soul-crushing exercise in futility. Driving your base around the battle field pumping out rock paper scissor style units as fast as they can be destroyed by the enemy base doing the same thing. This whole sequence is designed solely to annoy players. There’s no challenge here—just frustration. The difficulty comes from trying to keep playing without hurling your keyboard across the room. 

This game is not just bad—it’s a crime against humanity. They spent 15 years standing up against their competitors StarCraft, Age of Empires, and Supreme Commander just to throw it out the window to make Command and Conquer League of Legends version? For the very last game in the C&C series it was not the game ANYONE wanted. Were their not play testers? Whoever greenlit this disaster needs to reconsider their life choices. If you like Command and Conquer games I can recommend all of them up to this title. If you value your sanity, avoid this game like the plague.

column8:
This "game" stands as a cautionary tale against always-online games. Some day, those servers may not work anymore and the game will become unplayable. Imagine buying a book and a few years later the publisher gets bought out and suddenly the book's pages go blank. Buying always-online games is the equivalent to renting the game for as long as the developers decide to let you enjoy the product you paid for. Either pirate cracked copies or only support games that are truly offline compatible.

I played this game when it came out and it was honestly terrible for having such a prestigious name. Maybe the world is lucky that you can't even play it anymore.

column8:
An RTS with no base building and no resource gathering.

Units look cartoonish and ultra stylized, more like something out of warcraft than C&C. And you have to grind profile EXP to get points to unlock more advance units. What game does that? Oh wait, this one!

Campaign story is extremely short and pointless, added nothing to the overall Tiberium saga story except for the ending scene.

Not recommended.

column8:
In order to get this game working on Windows you need to do the steps below.
After these steps, I logged into the game on Windows and played it for a bit.
Got curious if I do the same for Steam Deck, if it would work ? It did. I didn't do any of the launch options for Windows and it just worked. I have no explanation. If you are a steam deck user, just wanted to throw this idea out there so you can maybe have a fighting chance.

Here is the SteamOS launch option version change the executable folder to yours: gamemoderun mangohud "/mnt/n_drive/SteamLibrary/steamapps/common/Command and Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight/Data/CNC4.game" -config "../CNC4_English.SkuDef" %command% 

These are copy pasted through the Steam Forums credit goes to MaxSixTux.
Some people say that they were able to get it working without this but sadly for me, all of the steps below had to be done. I like the C&C series and with the price this one has, normally I would recommend it but because its so broken and it might become completely unplayable really easily, I can't recommend it any shape or form.


--------------------
1) Went inside the C&C4 installation folder (where CNC4.exe is), and inside the compatibility tab, enabled the Administration mode for the executable.
2) Logged on inside ea.com with their account (not through Google account token or whatelse etc.) but with an account registered inside their servers. Changed the password in order to have just 8 characters and no special characters (like &%@ etc.)
3) Surfed on the net and found this website: https://gist.github.com/JeodC/cb7d632d1f20646defd0b2d180d43beb

Went in the "Tiberian Twilight" section and read what they wrote there. They stated that you have to go on Steam and put an start-up line:

cmd /c ""PATH-TO-GAMEFOLDER\Data\CNC4.game" -config "..\CNC4_English.SkuDef" %COMMAND%

if you check, there two " after /c. Leave them there, is not a typo. Change only the part "PATH-TO-GAMEFOLDER" with the path directory of C&C4 (if it contains spaces it doesnt matter). For example mine is: cmd /c ""E:\SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Command and Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight\Data\CNC4.game" -config "..\CNC4_English.SkuDef" %COMMAND%

Put the line inside the start-up command line inside Steam and double-check Steam got it right.

4) Launch the game. If everything is right, you should see a CMD prompt opening and the foreground window shrinking to 800x600. That's normal. The game will launch. THERE, you have to place the UserID (not the EA ID, the User ID that usually is an email address) and then the 8 character password. It should launch then login (like what happened to me). There's not much people connected, so it should work pretty smoothly.

5) Register a "commander" name and then continue with the main menu.
--------------------

column8:
Hated everything about it. Such a mood killer cause I was literally hype when The Scrins had such a big role in the Tiberium Saga and they had a really big introduction back in Tiberium Wars.

I was expecting a lot more when I saw the menu, saw the screenshots of this game from the page and thought that "hell yeah! the walkers are back!" But no! The Walkers are literally your base that's super useless, they added a level up thing, and worst of all........ A POPULATION LIMIT! BRO THIS AIN'T BATTLE REALMS FOR F**K SAKE!

If EA, and that is a BIG IF, ever decided to revive the franchise, I just wish that they would focus on a lot more in the story cause the whole cutscenes literally made me to roleplay the game like I was in it, hoping to become that one Commander to change everything. Games today shouldn't even be about graphics, gameplay or pro scenes, sometimes we all just want to enjoy it and Command and Conquer delivered that for me.

column8:
1. Ich hab'n Bug, kann keine Gebäude bauen.

2. Du brauchst eine aktive Internetverbindung... um es OFFLINE zu spielen.

3. Keine Online Funktion mehr möglich, Server wurden abgestellt. Spiel unterstützt keine Lan-Funktion, somit funktionieren auch VPNs wie Radmin/Hamachi nicht.

4. "Ironie on" geile Nod Cutscenes, ich wollte schon immer unseren Meister Proper Kane mit weißem Hintergrund sehen.

Das GUTE an dem Spiel: Endlich können Chrono Legionäre etwas sinnvolles tun.
column9:
1. I have a bug, I can't build buildings.

2. You need an active internet connection... to play it OFFLINE.

3. Online functionality is no longer possible, servers have been shut down. The game doesn't support LAN functionality, so VPNs like Radmin/Hamachi don't work either.

4. "Irony on" awesome Nod cutscenes, I've always wanted to see our Master Proper Kane with a white background.

The GOOD thing about the game: Chrono Legionnaires can finally do something useful.

战斗模式大改到被称为“王八竞技场”的程度，当然现在都知道本作是衍生品转正，也不知道EA高管抽的什么风。我寻思CC系列EA可没少榨，页游手游都有，怎么非要把这玩意转正啊。导致本作单人赶工的不像话还要套个莫名其妙的升级机制，终局之后也没新东西玩，经典的EA游戏生命周期。
可惜的是在当年简化RTS或者RTS转MOBA大潮中本作算是不那么拍脑袋而且有可玩性的那种，三种类型的基地把步兵/建筑、装甲/战场拾捡、空中/指令技拆开，人口限制规模简化操作，单位建造只需要时间方便转型，胜利点和科研点（泰晶）的博弈，刚出那阵5V5玩起来还是挺有意思的，但没有后续的东西自然是凉了个透。值得一提的是本作的单位是系列里最情怀的，什么都往里丢，2的悬浮导弹、巨像、NOD的钻地都扔里了，反正衍生作不需要在乎设定。如果当成独立作品长线运营说不准能把CC系列整个全塞进去，不过EA的长线……哈。

剧情不会写可以不写，设定改的天翻地覆赖不到赶工上，完全是存心的。凯恩从枭雄便乘有家回不去的可怜思金人，等了几千年最后成功润回去，思金巨塔的开启效果居然变成了消灭地球上所有泰晶恢复生态？虽然思金设定是挺俗的但这让思金变成啥了？宇宙环保大使么？于是凯恩升天成了双赢。而由此产生的十万个疑问中最重要的一条显然是：这个让三次泰伯利亚战争以及参战方便乘小丑的鬼故事到底是怎么通过审核并且真拍出来的？这就是他们的史诗结局？和质量效应3一样史诗是罢，突然开始担心龙腾4仂。

让回忆停留在CC3吧。
column9:
No one plays this game anymore. Why hasn't EA shut down the servers and switched it to a purely single-player game? You still have to log in to your EA account twice to access it.

The battle mode was overhauled to the point of being called "Turtle Arena." Of course, everyone knows this is a spin-off game being formalized. I don't know what's going on with EA executives. I think EA has been squeezing a lot out of the CC series, with both browser and mobile games, so why are they so desperate to formalize this one? This single-player game was rushed to completion, with a ridiculous leveling mechanic. There's nothing new to play after the endgame—a classic EA game lifecycle.

Unfortunately, in the era of simplified RTS or RTS-to-MOBA trends, this game was one of the less fussy and more playable. The three base types separated infantry/buildings, armor/battlefield pickup, and air/command skills. The population size limit simplified control. Unit construction took time to build, making it easy to transform. The battle between victory points and research points (Taijing) was quite fun in 5v5 when it first came out, but without further development, it naturally fizzled out. It's worth mentioning that this game's units are the most sentimental in the series. Everything is thrown in, from the hover missiles and Colossi from Tiberium 2 to the burrowing machine from Nod. After all, spin-offs don't need to worry about the setting. If it were a standalone, long-term project, it might even be able to fit the entire CC series into it, but EA's long-term plan... haha.

They can just leave it out if they can't write the plot, but the drastic changes to the setting can't be blamed on rushing; it's completely deliberate. Kane, ever since he was a tyrant, has been taking advantage of the poor Scrin, unable to return home. After waiting for thousands of years, he finally succeeds in returning. The activation of the Scrin Tower actually destroys all of Earth's Tiberium to restore the ecosystem? While the Scrin setting is rather cliché, what does this make the Scrin? Ambassadors of the universe's environment? So, Kane's ascension is a win-win for all. Of the 100,000 questions that arise, the most important one is obviously: How did this spooky story involving three Tiberium Wars and the clowns who participated in them get approved and actually filmed? Is this their epic ending? As epic as Mass Effect 3, right? Suddenly, I'm worried about Dragon's Ascension 4.

Let the memories stay in CC3.
