column8:
"глазки-РАЗВИДЕТЬ" вот с таким заклинанием я сидел после этого "чуда". Конечно предполагалось что игра может быть спасительным кругом своей новой системой боя...но это был лишь фарс. Игру загубили и изничтожили как только смогли, хуже не куда. 
Графика:
Помните ту полу/реалистичную графику в Command & Conquer 3, эфекты лучей Скриннов или солдат NOD? так вот сдесь ее не ждите,тут непобоюсь этого слова УБОГИЙ ГРАФОН, да-да именно убогий, такое ощущение что я играю во вторую часть,даже на максималках это не торт-еще четче видны косяки моделей.
Игровая механика:
Хотите отстраивать базу создавать крутю армию или использовать другие тактические штучки? вам не сюда идите дальше.
В начале боя выбираем один из трех типов МСЦ который выыполняет роль бараков/завода и всех сданий сразу, создаем ограниченное число юнитов и илем в лобовую ибо враги тупы как пробки.
Сюжет:
Думали на этом "вкусняшки" остались? а вот фиг! Сюжет проходишь с трудом,но не из-за сложности, а из-за убогости всего чего только можно; Кейна превратили в откровенног г*вно,он потерял весь свой шарм и харизму, даже фразы бравых фанатиков звучат как слова умственно отсталых...мир попросту невозможно изучать из-за отвратительности всего и вся на кажлм шагу

Вообщем серию загубили- игру заканчиваешь с большим трудом пересиливая себя ее не удалять ради просмотра финальных роликов. Разве то игра в которой нужно себя пересилить и закончить? Увы и ах-конец франщизе-эта часть поставила жирную точку если не крест.
column9:
"Unsee your eyes"—that's the spell I sat with after this "miracle." Of course, the game was supposed to be a lifeline with its new combat system... but it was a farce. They ruined the game as best they could, and it couldn't be worse.
Graphics:
Remember those semi-realistic graphics in Command & Conquer 3, the beam effects of the Scrin or the NOD soldiers? Well, don't expect that here. It's POOR GRAPHICS, and I'm not afraid to say it. Yes, absolutely POOR. It feels like I'm playing the second game. Even on maximum settings, it's not great—the model flaws are even more visible.
Game mechanics:
Want to build a base, create a cool army, or use other tactical tricks? This is not the place for you.
At the start of the battle, we choose one of three types of MSCs, which act as barracks/factory buildings and all the buildings at once. We create a limited number of units and attack head-on, because the enemies are as dumb as bricks.
Plot:
Did you think there were any "goodies" left? Nope! The plot is difficult to get through, not because of the difficulty, but because of the sheer wretchedness of everything. Kane has been turned into utter trash, he's lost all his charm and charisma, even the phrases of the brave fanatics sound like the words of the mentally retarded... the world is simply impossible to explore because of the disgusting nature of everything at every turn.

In short, they've ruined the series—you finish the game with great difficulty, forcing yourself not to delete it just to watch the final cutscenes. Is this really a game where you have to force yourself to finish it? Alas and alack - the end of the franchise - this part put a bold point, if not a cross.

column8:
Ich empfehle euch das spiel NICHT zu kaufen! 

Die Vorgänger von C&C waren um einiges besser. EA scheint wohl nur noch schnell Geld verdienen zu wollen. Nach einer Anmeldung in Origin (wobei das sehr unverständlich für mich ist da das Spiel in Steam ausreichend geschützt ist) bin ich dann ins Game gekommen.

So misserable war noch kein anderes C&C. Mit nur einer Spielmodi (Herrschaft) wird es schnell langweilig. 

Wer Wert auf große Schlachten und langes Spielvergnügen setzt sollte dieses Game meiden!
column9:
I recommend you DO NOT buy this game!

The predecessors to C&C were much better. EA seems to just want to make a quick buck. After signing up in Origin (which I find quite incomprehensible, as the game is sufficiently protected on Steam), I finally got into the game.

No other C&C has ever been this miserable. With only one game mode (Domination), it gets boring quickly.

Anyone who values ​​big battles and long-lasting gameplay should avoid this game!

column8:
Eins vorweg: Ich spiele C&C seit 1995, habe jeden Teil mehrfach durchgespielt, auch auf den höchsten Schwierigkeitsstufen und diverse Online und Lan Matches hinter mir. Kenne mich dementsprechend mit der Materie aus.

Kurzfassung

Ja, man kann das Spiel, wenn man es wie ich im Angebot kauft durchweg spielen, sollte es jedoch NICHT zu C&C zählen, dann macht das Spiel durchaus Spaß, auf wenn man egal mit welchem Crawler, einer mobilen Einheit die ähnlich der mobilen Waffenfabrik von Tiberian Sun ist, man eigentlich nur vor die gegnerische Basis fährt und den Gegner mit Einheiten totwirft.

Langfassung

Kampagne: Neben dem, schnellen und recht lustigen Multiplayer ist die Kampagne ja das eigentliche Augenmerk, leider wurde hier viel verändert. Der Spielcharakter ist mal wieder namenlos, hat diesmal eine Ehefrau in den Cutscenes die ebenfalls nicht mehr die Klasse anderer Teile erreichen. Die Charaktere sind, zumindest für mich unbekannt, flach, überspitzt kitschig und mit für mich unbekannten Schauspielern besetzt. Storyline mehr als flach, aber ich will hier nicht spoilern.

Grafik

Ungefähr auf höhe von Tiberium Wars, somit immer noch die Generäle Engine, die trotzdem irgendwie "eckig" wirkt in sachen Einheitenbewegung und Crawlerplatzierung, ähnlich Alarmstufe Rot 3.

Sound

Durchaus okay, bekannte Sprecher, EVA von der gleichen Person gesprochen wie in Tiberium Wars. Leider fehlt knackiges Geschützfeuer.

In eigener Sache

Leider wurde mal wieder einiges geändert, abgesehen vom Crawlersystem. C&C 4 sollte eigentlich ein Onlinespiel nur für den Asiatischen Raum sein und somit Starcraft ebenbürtig werden. Die Kampagne kam erst im nachhinein, das erklärt viele Logiklücken. Die typischen C&C Waffen wurden durch realistische wie z.B. P90 in Cutscenes geändert, die Hintergründe sind nur blinkende Computerwände, ähnlich Carters Versuchslabor bei Stargate SG1. Die GDI Uniformen wurden ebenfalls gegen realistische Uniformen getauscht. Zwar haben beide Seiten wieder SciFi Einheiten wie man es in der Zukunft auch erwartet, doch komsicherweise haben alle Leute scheinbar einen totalblackout, da scheinbar keiner mehr weiß das Schallwaffen Tiberiumkristalle zerstören. Die Liste geht noch um einige Punkte weiter, aber ich denke man versteht was ich sagen will.

Fazit

Nettes Skirmish/Multiplayerspiel, mit Online und EA Registrierungszwang, aber 0 Storyline. Ironischerweise sind die Entwickler teilweise jünger als ich selbst, vielleicht liegt bei der u20 Generation die akzeptanz für Action statt Story höher.

7,5 von 10 Punkten
column9:
First of all: I've been playing C&C since 1995, have completed every installment multiple times, even on the highest difficulty levels, and have played various online and LAN matches. Accordingly, I'm quite familiar with the subject matter.

Short version

Yes, you can play the game all the way through if you buy it on sale like I did. However, if you don't consider it C&C, then the game is definitely fun, especially if you use any crawler, a mobile unit similar to Tiberian Sun's mobile weapons factory, and all you do is drive to the enemy base and blast the enemy with units.

Long version

Campaign: Besides the fast and quite fun multiplayer, the campaign is the real focus, but unfortunately, a lot has been changed. The player character is once again nameless, and this time he has a wife in the cutscenes, which also don't reach the quality of other installments. The characters are, at least not familiar to me, shallow, exaggeratedly cheesy, and filled with actors I don't know. The storyline is more than shallow, but I don't want to spoil it here.

Graphics

Roughly on par with Tiberium Wars, so it still uses the Generals Engine, which nevertheless feels somewhat "angular" in terms of unit movement and crawler placement, similar to Red Alert 3.

Sound

Quite okay, familiar voice actors, EVA voiced by the same person as in Tiberium Wars. Unfortunately, crisp gunfire is missing.

On a personal note

Unfortunately, a lot has been changed again, apart from the crawler system. C&C 4 was originally supposed to be an online game only for the Asian region and thus on par with Starcraft. The campaign came later, which explains many of the logical gaps. The typical C&C weapons were replaced with realistic ones, such as the P90, in cutscenes; the backgrounds are just flashing computer walls, similar to Carter's test lab in Stargate SG1. The GDI uniforms were also replaced with realistic ones. While both sides have sci-fi units again, as one would expect in the future, strangely enough, everyone seems to have a complete blackout, as no one seems to remember that sonic weapons destroy Tiberium crystals. The list goes on for a few more points, but I think you get the point.

Conclusion

Nice skirmish/multiplayer game, with online and EA registration required, but zero storyline. Ironically, some of the developers are younger than me; perhaps the under-20 generation is more likely to accept action than story.

7.5 out of 10 points

column8:
Terrible. Absolutely the worst C&C game ever made, without a doubt, I don't know how EA could make C&C 3 so incredibly amazing and then do a couplete U-turn and make this. This may well be the worst game I have ever had the misfortune to play. I paid under £5 for this and it was still too much. I feel like EA should be paying us to play this.
The "always-online" that EA has a big hard-on for lately is a nightmare.
The only reason I bought this was to concluce the CnC tiberium storyline and even that was terrible. Did you know there's no more tiberium in this game? Literally, it's pretty much all gone. No base building, no harvesting resources. You can train units without any cost but only up to a very, very limited unit cap. I'm talking REAL limited. Like you can only train enough units to have a decent attack force or a decent defense force. Not both. I expect that kind of limit on a console RTs but not PC.

DO
NOT
BUY

column9:
Tiberian Twilight... aka "Chapter 4."

Unlike the traditional C&C gameplay of "resource gathering -> base construction -> production -> battle," this game attempts a genre shift with a more territorial RTS style, similar to those of Com-Oh, Warhammer, and Z.

While it's disappointing that such a heterogeneous game is officially numbered "Chapter 4" and not a spin-off, the gameplay itself is passable, regardless of its predecessors.

Finally, we get to see the Ascension of Cain.

column8:
The only reason to buy a copy of this utter travesty of a game is to burn it. If you're a fan of the Command and Conquer series, if you remember them fondly from your youth, if you've played any other RTS, no matter how bad, all this will do is make you die a little inside. 

One copy needs to be saved to act as a warning from history. An example of things that must never be repeated. I'm sure EA will keep one somewhere. Burn the rest and delete anything digital. Please.

column8: For anybody who loved the older Command and Conquer games: STAY AWAY! Command and Conquer 4 strays so far from the original Command and Conquer formula that it is virtually unrecognizable as a Command and Conquer game. Gone is the base building and resource gathering, replaced with a "mobile crawler" and a rather stifling hard "population cap" as well as a need to gather experience to unlock other units. What Electronic Arts was thinking when they put this one together is beyond me, and while it may have been a good game on its own, it's not a Command and Conquer game.

column8:
Don't listen to the people who say this game sucks. C&C4 is a legitimate step forward in RTS mechanics, distilling the fun of what you used to call "base building" in the game's offense/defense/support crawlers. 

I picked Defense and played through the campaign. Guess what, it's anything but "Defense." If you could call crawling up in the enemy lines, plopping down defense towers and bunkers next to their shit, and letting your therefore heavily shielded infantry tear everyone up, "defense." 

The game shows that there is pretty much no need for RTS games to go through the traditional stages of build-up and then push. In this game, you just push. Or get pushed. All day. Can't take it, well, there's Starcraft for you people who like having to memorize tons of bullshit before actually playing the game.

See, there's a reason why people enjoy games like DOTA-like games. It's because they took the fun parts out of the RTS and put them in a game by itself. Give C&C4 some credit for doing the same thing but for base building, army composition, and micro. In time you guys are going to look at games like C&C4 as the first (though mis-advertised) baby steps toward actual computerized strategy games where it's easy to pick up and play but the strategy is really deep like chess and Go.

This game killed all that C&C have built up over the years. Thay took all that C&C stand for and trow it away.
No base building, no resource gathering and Scrin whas gone even if i whas not that huge fan of them geting in Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars. But taking out the main core of the game and re-build the game to have walkers making units for you and tiberium nodes and crystals that give you upgrade points. The lvl system for unlocking units and upgrades is not good for a singelplayer or multiplayer.

I do not recommend that anyone buy this game even if thay are a C&C hardcore fans.

column8: This game is everything that is wrong with the C&C series. Ever since the closing of Westwood Studios the entire franchise has been plummeting to it's death brought about by a starvation for innovative game play that remains true to the original series. Tiberian Twilight proves that there are no new good ideas left and C&C needs to be put to bed or have the reigns handed off to someone more responsible. This game ended up being one of the worst RTSs I have ever played and the person who bought it for me felt the need to apologize for the rotten pile of progamming that sits in a place of dishonor amongst my Steam games. Do not buy this and do not play it.

column8: I have been a lifelong CnC fan, but this game really screwed up the formula rather than innovate it. The lack of base building or resource gathering means that the game is just a mad rush to build as may units as possible, throw them at the enemy, and repeat. Only one of the classes can build defenses. the leveling up system means that you are grossly underpowered in multiplayer matches until you grind up to the top. This complelety destroys the balance as you could only have access to tanks while your opponent is using Mastadons. Also, the story and the acting is awful. It's college level bad.

column8:
Tiberian Twilight does not deserve the Command & Conquer title. It's a chugging slow C&C wannabe with kindergarten storyline, irritating and clumsy interface, and a huge learning curve even if you've played the series from day 1. Also dont expect to be able to play AT ALL if for some reason you're unable to connect to the internet. 

While C&C3 kept me busy for hundreds of hours, this one made me feel complelled to leave mid mission, before my first hour was up. I'll need to be seriously drunk or delirious to try this one again.

column8: If your looking for the same awesome RTS experience as the previous Command and Conquer Tiberian titles, then do not get this game. Playing this game literally depressed me. I have no clue what EA was thinking when they made this game it is so beyond god awful I just don't know how else to describe it. The camping is boring, i find that I pretty much have to force myself to play it. In the other installments of C&C I couldn't leave my computer because it was just so addicting. This game is a disappointment and a waste of money to even the most hard core fans.

column9: The worst game in the entire Command & Conquer series—zero plot, monotonous online battles as King of the Hill, no traditional base building, and no Tiberium gathering. They even managed to bully Kane so much that he doesn't even show the usual emotions in-game. They promised revelations about the entire Tiberium Saga, but nothing came of it. Kane didn't reveal any of his secrets and ran off who knows where. But at least the music is fantastic. We hope they correct these mistakes in a potential Command & Conquer 5.

column8:
Das Gameplay hat nicht nur nix mehr mit C&C zu tun.

Es is praktisch schlechtes "DOTA" für das C&C Universum ... viel Geklicke, gar kein Effekt.

Mit dem Genre"Echtzeit-Strategiespiel" hat es sicher nix mehr zu tun. Schon gar nicht mit dem Stil des Genres, den die Reihe ursprünglich geschaffen hat.

Wie es sich anfühlt: Mit Glück grob das produzieren, was man braucht. In der Regel 2 Drittel auf ein Thema, den Rest "Wirr mischen". Mehr als 20 Einheiten wird man nie haben, also von jeder etwas, und a bissi was um die "Base" des Gegners anzughen.

Fakt ist, man kann sein MBF am besten gleich neben dem Gegner MBF parken ... denn wer das Lotto der Units besser mischt, zerstört das MBF ... aber man kann ja ein neues holen.

Unterm Strich heißt das:
- Taktik-Frei
- Resourcen-Frei
- Chaos pur

1% von 100% auf "Tolles Spiel" ... 1% weil, es immerhin nette Videosequenzen hat.
column9:
Not only does the gameplay no longer have anything to do with C&C, but it's practically a bad "DOTA" for the C&C universe... lots of clicking, no effect at all.

It certainly has nothing to do with the "real-time strategy game" genre anymore. And certainly not with the style of the genre the series originally created.

How it feels: With luck, you can produce roughly what you need. Usually, two-thirds on one theme, the rest "mixed up randomly." You'll never have more than 20 units, so a little of each, and a little something to attack the enemy's "base."

The fact is, it's best to park your MBF right next to the enemy MBF... because whoever shuffles the unit lotto better will destroy the MBF... but you can always get a new one.

The bottom line is:
- Tactics-free
- Resource-free
- Pure chaos

1% of 100% for "Great game"... 1% because it at least has nice cutscenes.

column9:
I downloaded it hoping to experience the "good old" Command & Conquer, but instead got another Warhammer 40k clone with an online focus. They even didn't bother to create a NOD campaign. Overall, I don't recommend it for fans of old-school strategy games, and online combat enthusiasts are unlikely to find anything special or new. It's the same old checkpoint grind and the pathetic "building" component. I don't know about you, but I'm pretty fed up with this "primitivization."

In 2023, they stopped accepting keys; the developers simply stole the money I paid for their piece of crap.

column8: Pretty much as bad as you have heard. The campaign is a very brief set of 17 missions, 3 tutorial and 7 each for GDI/Nod. The story is on par with a cheesy Sci-fi Channel movie and is largely the same for both factions. Gameplay's not terrible once you get used to it, but it's pretty boring.  The main challenge is the incredibly small unit cap which in turn leads to an incredibly small army. This is exacerbated by the bonus units found on most maps which are counted in the cap and can put you over the cap. So if a crucial unit like the repair Engineer is lost you can wind up in a situation where you have to self-destruct 2 or more units to replace 1 that was destroyed. You also have to "level up" in order to access the higher tier units even in the single player, though in practice most of the bonus units are the powerful tier 3 so this is more inconvenient than anything.

column8: Command & Conquer Tiberian series. Possibly the best RTS games ever made. Deep and compelling story, Unique units and factions, Balanced, easy to learn and loads of fun. Very few people can say anything bad about the Tiberian series. Then there is this ball of rot. Looks bad, terrible story, horrible voice acting. Is this even a Command & Conquer game? People used to say C&C Generals was bad. I doubt anything could be as bad as this game. My advice? Don't buy this game, and if it's free....don't even bother taking it. Just say NO.

column8:
Do not get this game. It's an awful, terrible, extremely sad neuterization of the C&C series.

Given that you still think you may like it, consider this: In order to actually do anything (multiplayer) you must unlock units. You start with a whopping 3 total uinits: light infantry, light vehicle and tank. All of which are completely worthless if you play against someone who has, for some reason, put time into the game. And that is just scratching the surface of the problems!

Even if this product is on sale for 90% off, avoid it at all costs.

column9:
Just kill me, please. The graphics are terrible, there's no combat tactics, no balance.
For example, if you're playing online and you're level 1, you have almost no access to anything. And then you're thrown in with some level 80 who builds an avatar at the start of the game, and gg wp is easy for you.
The units are terribly designed =_= You could say they ruined this amazing series. We hope the developers come to their senses and return everything to how it was in 3.

column8:
EA screwed up big time on this one. 
They failed the developers who had built an moderately interesting fast-paced RTS game that really had nothing to do with C&C and slapped the brand name on it, hoping it might sell to some hardcore C&C fans. The game itself never got the chance it might have deserved, because it could never be judged on its own merits but always as "The Conclusion to the Tiberium Saga".
They failed the fans of the previous games, because they delivered something that did not understand the value of the gameplay of all the previous titles and threw out time-honored traditions just for the sake of cleaning house.
They even managed to fail the brand itself. If EA has to send out an email that ensures "fans" that they have brought back resource harvesting, removed unit caps and similar basic fundamantals, then it is very clear that the brand itself have lost tremendous value and C&C4 almost solely bears that whole responsibility.
Overall this game fails, not because of what it is, but for what it sets out to be.

column8:
Took over an hour to get the game started, not counting download time. First attempt resulted in computer rebooting during NET.framework installation. Second time involved a 20min wait while NET.framework installed, then half an hour chasing round for account details, the login screen's link led to an endless loop of entering an email and a code, never once saying 'By the way, you already have an account under that email, you're wasting your time.'

Once all these hoops have been jumped through to the games satisfaction, navigating a somewhat awkward setup menu to start a simple 1v1 skirmish with the ai, to get accustomed to the game. It would seem by default a section of the HUD is missing, map for instance is cut off at about 2/3, only showing the middle and right third. Also lack of a menu button, unless mapped to something suitably awkward, or possibly on the cut off section of the display made exiting to alter settings very awkward.

A ctrl+alt+delete, 5 end task and 1 terminate process later, we come to the third attempt, resulting in entire system locking up and the plug being pulled.

Net result, I want a refund, but terms and conditions state that's not going to happen, so here's to a waste of money.

column8:
My overall rating 4 out of 5 stars

Honestly i don't understand why this game got such bad reviews. At no point are you ever forced into multiplayer, like one of the previous reviews said. I've been playing the campaigns and did a few skirmish maps with the AI to level my profile. Which does lead into one partial negative. That being the near necessity of playing one of the campaigns before you start skirmish modes. Apperently the unlocks are tied to yoru profile rank which is persistant in the campaign and skirmish. 

Game play's not really that aweful as some have described. It's more of a elite squad based kind of strategy take on C&C. That may be off putting to some, but you do have a "base building" option with the defense crawler. Just don't expect massive bases like in C&C3. I did find myself useing the offensive crawlers a little bit more than i would have liked.

So the story lines a little anti climactic. Sadly given that it's the end of the series, it would have been near impossible to have actually finished it properly for the majority of the fan base. So i can't fault it for that, though i do find fault in how the cutscenes follow through. It's like there are parts missing. That being said, if you run both campaigns, you'll get alot of the plot holes filled in by the opossite campaign.

I haven't tried multiplayer yet, but when i get a chance, i'll add that review.

column8:
I'd give this game 1/5 stars.

In all fairness, the gameplay is a completely different concept from the previous games. As a concept it's... unique and might have some potential, but they certainly didn't pull it off. If you're looking for a steroidal version of Tiberian Sun and Tiberian Wars, this isn't it. If you're looking for closure to the series, then the end of the storyline is worse than the books following Ender's Game and Ender's Shadow. The story is stupid, the acting is worse, and more immature and childish than Red Alert. Do you really want to know how this series ends? Fine, here it is: Kane makes peace with GDI for free, and in both the GDI and NOD campaigns you are protecting Kane on his quest to cross the portal to join the aliens. The end. Horrible game, total waste of time and money, horrible end to an otherwise great story.

column8:
Как можно мучительно "убить" франшизу? Франшиза необязательно должна умереть с закрытием студии оригинального разработчика. И необязательно умрёт с добавлением резких, кардинально новых деталей в процессе естественной эволюции серии в новой части. Но Франшиза всегда умирает, когда теряет свои корни и основы.
В C&C4 франшиза умерла с лёгкой подачи своего издателя - EA. Потому что в компании кто-то решил, что для бизнеса будет гораздо лучше, если новая часть будет совсем другой. В итоге мы получили следующее. Все базовые и незыблемые основы геймплея C&C спилены накорню, сюжет убог, обрезан и лишён смысловой нагрузки (И харизма Джо "Кейна" Кукана в этот раз не спасает). Вместо классических баз - три вида разбалансированных штаба, выбор между которыми всегда очевиден. Отсутствие классической экономики и ресурсов, скучные и лишённые тактики сражения. Роль Тибериума здесь -  отвечать за прокачку бесполезных и ограниченных в своей механике скиллов. И всё это безусловно печалит...
В игру не хочется играть, игровой мир не хочется изучать.  Приходится заставлять себя проходить сюжетку ради финальных роликов. А если играть приходится через силу - то что же это за игра? Где удовольствие?
column9:
How can you painfully "kill" a franchise? A franchise doesn't necessarily die with the closure of the original developer's studio. And it doesn't necessarily die with the addition of drastic, radically new elements during the natural evolution of the series in a new installment. But a franchise always dies when it loses its roots and foundations.
In C&C4, the franchise died at the behest of its publisher, EA. Because someone at the company decided it would be much better for business if the new game was completely different. The result is this. All the basic and unshakable foundations of C&C gameplay were completely erased, the story is pathetic, truncated, and devoid of meaning (and Joe "Kane" Kukan's charisma doesn't save it this time). Instead of classic bases, there are three types of unbalanced headquarters, the choice between which is always obvious. The absence of a classic economy and resources, boring and tactically devoid battles. Tiberium's role here is to boost useless skills that are mechanically limited. And all of this is undoubtedly sad...
I don't want to play the game, I don't want to explore the world. I have to force myself to play through the story just for the final cutscenes. And if I have to force myself to play, what kind of game is it? Where's the fun?

The campaign still leaves many questions unanswered.

column8:
An utter abomination of a game that only earns the right to use the C&C logo because of the live action story involving Joe Kucan as Kane.  Seriously, C&C4 completely abandons every core element of what made the Command and Conquer identity in the first place.  #1) Battles take place more in arena venues than true story dictated maps.  #2) Your unit count is so small that you can forget building an army #3) You cannot build base fortresses and your production capabilities are easily lost and recovered meaning you've got nothing important to defend and no ultimate goal in smashing your opponent's key structure. #4) The ingame economy is so simplified and anemic that it removes any remaining strategic decisions so that it becomes impossible to out-produce your opponent. #5) Progress is slow and boring since you must tediously earn experience points in order to unlock better units. #6) The visual language of the unit designs is no longer clear making it very hard to understand why one unit is superior to another, and not only that but all the units are extremely wimpy with little ability to decisevly break through enemy forces.

C&C4 started out as an experimental idea for a cheaply made free-to-play RTS game and was then forcibly upgraded into a C&C game.  The live action story moments are the only thing worth mentioning about this game to anyone with a passing care about the Command Conquer franchise and for that just go to Youtube where you can see it all for free.  

What a terrible, unforgiveable waste of time and resources this game is.

column8:
Fraudulent. A mockery.

This game isn't as bad as they say it is ... it's worse!!! :( Like me, you might think "It's C&C. how bad can it be?" Answer: world-class bad. A complete corruption of the art form by people who don't understand the first thing about what made C&C cool and different from other RTSes, and have ruined the franchise. Highlights: no more concept of "economy" or "base-building"; plodding, ineffectual units; linear "progression" of uninspired unlocks, meanwhile each faction can build fewer units -- not to mention structures -- than ever before; and of course a laughable "story".  C&C has "wives" in it now, did u know?

Overall, it just exudes that particular EA-Games flavor of disgust. $5 I wish I had back, and the bottom line: wherever you may rate this game on the scale from "just plain" bad to "seriously I can't believe how bad it is" bad, your time is most assuredly better spent elsewhere.

Disclaimer: I never met a C&C I didn't like. ( .................... up until RA3 which, questionable as it may be, is still infinitely more playable and "C&C" than /this/ POS.)

column8:
Out of all of the Command & Conquer games I've played, this is the only one I've ever regretted buying. As it's shown through gameplay, it does NOT resemble the traditional build-up-your-base-and-army aspects seen in most of the previous games (Renegades is an FPS game). There's a limit on how much units you can use at one time. It's also not a destroy-the-enemy-base game anymore as it's more like a hold down points of the map type of game.

However, the biggest disappointment I found would be the online portion. First, an internet connection is required at all times even if you're not playing online. Second, because there's a level up system which determines how much you can use (and both factions have separate level progresses), it limits a player's choices within the first hours or days of playing. Lastly, playing online can match people unfairly (players may have considerably large level gaps), leading to games where a new player doesn't have the units a higher level player does, especially powerful ones.

If you're a player who has played CnC games throughout the years, it's likely you'll be disappointed with the change in gameplay mechanics. I really don't think this game is worth playing, but that doesn't exactly mean I'm saying "don't buy it". Buy it if you want, I'm just saying it's not worth it.

column8:
Command and Conquer what happened to you. You used to be the king of RTS. Your cheesy live action cut-scenes were the stuff of legend and we eagerly anticipate your every release.
Now what have you done to yourself? No resources, no armies, no bases? What is this? A shadow of what used to be?
YOU ARE NOT COMPANY OF HEROES!
Why can't you stay the way you used to be? We all loved you and cherished every memory of you? Why do you have to cheapen what we have?
Why? WHY? WHY?!

It is difficult for me to articulate my feelings about Command & Conquer 4 Tiberian Twilight. All I really know is, I don't like it.

In some misguided attempt by what I can only assume is an ill-informed marketing department somewhere deep in the bowels of the EA mega structure this installment of the Command & Conquer franchise changes everything about the previous games. They even went so far as to remove the live action cut-scenes that, despite being where B-movie stars go to die, had become a benchmark in the industry.

You no longer build bases or harvest Tiberium, instead you get allocated a number of points that can be spent on units, when a unit die you get your points back and can try a new combination. It takes what used to be a very balanced RTS experience and turns it into an entirely micromanagement experience, and not a terribly good one at that.

This is not unlike what you might see in the later Dawn of War games but where Dawn of War balanced it with RPG elements making each unit seem important here you are just sending mindless, faceless entities towards a bunch of other mindless, faceless entities in the hope of beating the map objective before you mind rots from the monotone boredom.

Command & Conquer might be viewed by many as the classic simple RTS, but it was the one that monopolized the best on that approach and it was the franchise that more than any other made the real time strategy genre a force to be reckoned with.

Now it is nothing more a boring mediocre clone of a game, trying to do with all the other cool new RTS's are doing but not doing it nearly as well and losing what made the game special in the first place in the attempt.

It is a sad end for what was once such a proud franchise. The older Command & Conquer games will forever hold a special place in my heart but this makes me hope the series will die before another abomination is released.

column8: Command and Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight (C&C4) is the lackluster follow up and conclusion to the beloved Tiberium storyline of the Command and Conquer series. While crucial for story-enthused players, C&C4 breaks up the traditional base building and attempts to create a rank-based multiplayer game. The constant mobility leaves you feeling that every mission is a commando-based offshoot and fails to satisfy classic real-time strategy fans. The ranked multiplayer makes most matches feel unbalanced, but  there are opportunities for co-op gameplay. All in all, C&C4 leaves much to be desired in every aspect, but the game still holds the conclusion to the series.

column8: The C&C franchise has always had quality games but they really dropped the ball on this installment. As the last game in the Kane saga, you would expect the story to be the best out of all the previous games. Unfortunately, the story is extremely short, confusing, and just plain boring at times. The game mechanics has also gone through a complete overhaul, but this change is not for the better. The gameplay is just too simple now that they've taken away building structures, resource mining, and the removal of some staple units. The new interface will probably throw off a lot of old C&C players as well. The biggest issue for me was with the balance of the game. You can build any unit extremely fast and since resources are gone, you aren't punished that much for losing all your forces. The only thing that made the game bearable was the co-op. Other than that, this game deviates too far from the series and I'd only recommend getting it for cheap and if you want to see how it all ends.

column8: Решительно не рекомендую игру!! Думал сначала, все зря так распыляются на геймплей, посмотрю лучше сюжет, ведь интересно, что стало с Тацидом и как будет вновь вести себя Кейн, но НЕТ!! И сюжет оказался очень быстр, лёгок, глуп, и персонажи странные, и Кейн не столь грозен как в "Ярости"!! Отвратно даже было сначала, что драгоценный тацид, который я потом и кровью зарабатывал, мы просто так отдали и ещё о нём перестали говорить, опустили!! Да и геймплей соглашусь - дрянь, нужна новая стратегия, отличная от предыдущих частей...
column9: I strongly recommend this game! At first, I thought everyone was wasting their time on the gameplay and that I'd rather watch the story, because I'd be interested in what happened to Tacide and how Kane will behave again. But NO! The plot turned out to be too quick, too easy, and too stupid, and the characters were weird, and Kane wasn't as menacing as in "Fury"! It was even disgusting at first that we just gave away the precious Tacide I'd worked so hard to earn, and then they stopped talking about it, completely ignored it! And I agree – the gameplay is crap; it needs a new strategy game, different from the previous games...

column8: Obwohl Command & Conquer drauf steht und Kane mit dabei ist, ist es leider kein Command & Conquer. column9: Although it says Command & Conquer on the label and Kane is in it, it's unfortunately not Command & Conquer. It's actually the worst game in the series; everything that made Command & Conquer great—base building, resource mining, etc.—was simply removed, meaningless, and a pseudo-base building system was added, complete with a troop limit. If you buy it on Steam for €2-3 like I did, okay, it's not worth much more than that.

column9: It's a disgrace, avoid it like the plague. They've completely transformed the gameplay into something awkward and frustrating. You have to slap them in the face two at a time until they become odd. It's not a gift.

column8:
In this sci-fi baldpunk RTS, you play as Commander Married to Giant Forehead: The Woman. After getting your eyes replaced with plot devices, you must decide between siding with Kain, Grand Poobah of the Brotherhood of Mod, many of them have been lead astray by such evils as skyrim JRPG mods. However, Commander Crazy Black Lady refuses to see the good MOD can bring to humanity so she kills your wife after you agree to side with her to ensure your loyalty.

So after you fail to pay your phone bill so you can't call your homies at PDA to tell them to stop shooting, you kill them and then regardless of whichever path you take, Commodore Baldington says "F*** this shit, I'm going into space" and then he goes into Space, the end.

column8:
I'll be honest here, I've not played this game much. I spent maybe five minutes in a skirmish game then quit; it does not stay true to the original Command & Conquer games, which is why I've not given it much time. Basebuilding is minimal and there's something about capturing points alike Company of Heroes, World in Conflict or Dawn of War 2, who all seem to have done it better than this game.

Though, as I said, I'm being honest when I say I've not played this; if you see it cheap and want to complete your C&C collection, then you'll be no worse than me. How much time you spend actually playing it is up to you. 

I appreciate comments on my recommendation if you've played this after being a fan of the originals, let me know your thoughts; I'm simply too biased to spend another minute playing this.

column8:
Unfortunately, this game is worse than its critic reviews indicate.

This game reeks of a rush job, as if EA was hurriedly seeking to close out and move from the CNC franchise. To call it underwhelming and disappointing is an understatement. Stay away unless you really feel compelled to complete your CNC collection.

GAMEPLAY
In one word: boring.

Harsh limits on the number of units you can control makes this feel like a tactical game, with none of the visceral satisfaction often seen in those games. The game is heavily based on counters/hard counters, but even in disparate matchups by this system, the  encounters take forever to finish.

Combine this with how easy it is to replace lost units, and missions quickly become a slog.

The singleplayer is a total dud in all aspects. Missions are linear and short, and there aren't many of them. The cutscenes show a similar lack of dedication, being completely forgettable and doing little to actually wrap up the Tiberium universe story.

The multiplayer was occasionally entertaining, but given that is rarely the reason I play an RTS, it was immaterial for me.

GRAPHICS/AUDIO
Technically speaking, they aren't bad. However, the cartoony visuals are at odds with the rest of the Tib universe (including CNC3), and unit designs are both bland and uninspired. Much of the same can be said about the audio.


No franchise deserves an end like this.

column8:
If you liked earlier Command & Conquer games, then stay the F away from this one.
They took all that was good and tossed it away.
This game shouldnt even have "Tiberian" in it.
I mean, there is barely any tiberium in this piece of shit (well, except the intro video..)

And the story is complete shit. Let me sum it up, spoilers ahead:
Kane has glowing ball, ball makes tiberium behave, GDI and Kane has built tiberium-pipelines together. And on every map, every side has a reason to kill you somehow.
It ends with Kane going home thru portals, and your reward for that sucks. Always.

But its a RTS right?? Well its a RTS-Unit spamfest game. Not much thinking besides having as many units as possible alive at the same time.

The only good thing is the ability to play cooperative with another poor soul (friend).
So there is no need to play this shit alone/singleplayer...

In short: Do not buy it. (unless you get it for free, or from a friend) :D   (Thanks mate!) )

UPDATE: Gamespy is down, multiplayer/coop may not work. +DRM can prevent re-install.
Nominated game for the "You ruined the franchise! GOD DAMN YOU ALL TO HELL!" -award.

column8:
So, I was in the break room at work one day, and there's this car insurance commercial on the television. Two co-workers are watching it, laughing to themselves over the absurdity that each insurance company claims to be the single best provider. "They can't all be the best at the same time," says one. I agreed, adding that it's much like how each religion insists that it is the only true belief. I'm met with a look and, "Well, I know I have the one true Word and the one true God." I shrugged and said, "Oh, I have State Farm."

Long story short? Never, ever play C&C4:TT. It's more awkward than discussing religion at the workplace and rarely ends with such a quippy anecdote.

column8: Command & Conquer 4 is enjoyable for gamers who loved World In Conflict. Tiberian Twilight steers well clear from the original gameplays of its predecessors. Instead, it adapts a domination-style capture control point mode which is widely seen in World In Conflict, Dawn of War, and Company of Heroes. The visuals are from an upgraded version of the RAGE engine and performs well in the fast-packed crawler multiplayer rush battles.

While different from the other CNC games, it has a greatness about it. The simple, yet action packed style of the game makes for great LAN parties. The co-op campaign was a great idea too.

The only thing I dislike about the game, is you unlock more units to use on each side by playing that side. So you can go up against the computer/other people who have more options than you do just because they have played more.

column8:
This game is alright if you do not judge it but the game play found in the older games. This is much more about fewer stronger units, than base and army building. That considered, the game modes given offer a challenge and it is neat to work to unlock units. It is not fun however to play online against players who already have very unit unlocked and know the quickest way to win. The single player portion of the game has a some what corny story that manages to be legitimate and includes with it some live action cinematics, with familiar characters, that are of similar quality. I would say though its a great effort and you are not there for the cinematics any way so it's easily forgiven. 

Overal its an alright game but multilayer is not for the casual gamer unless it's among friends.

column8: As an avid RTS player CnC 4 strays from traditional RTS games and focus's on action.  The game has some RPG elements to it which you can cap within 10 hours of non stop playing.  The dev's did away with base building and resource gathering instead you get a crawler similar to a command center which is mobile.  It creates all your units.  You get 3 crawlers to choose from either side.  Support, Offense and Defense each class has it's own unique unit's and abilities.  At first I enjoyed this game.  But removing resources and base's takes away a huge elemnet of why enjoy RTS games to begin with.  No economy to manage and no real "home" to protect 2 factors which add depth to RTS's.  Being able to manage those and your army add's alot to the gameplay and I miss it when playing this game.  If you don't appreciate those things in RTS's and prefer to get right into the action then this game is for you.  But not so much for me.  I bought it mainly to see the conclusion to the storyline. 6/10

column8: To anyone who respects this series.... DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. I understand that EA was trying to inovate the classic RTS and went in with the best intentions; but they butchered it. Missions feel generic and bases are non-existent. I like the idea of the mobile bases, which has already been done in C&C2; but I feel as though I'm playing Dawn of War 2 rather than a C&C game. I played through a few skrimishes and about 8 missions. The learning curve is incredibly steep even on normal difficulty and the computer is unforgiving even in the first campaign missions. Lastly the game is more about how many units I can produce rather than using group tactics and formations. Do yourself a favor and go buy C&C3 kane's wrath. It is a much better game with a better structure of gameplay.

column8:
NOT C&C!!  STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME!!!

September 2020 UPDATE:

Still a horrible mess of a game. The only thing that resembles C&C in this title is Kane, and even that is lackluster at best. 
The mechanics that made the C&C genre great are all missing from this. A complete waste of time and money.
This is a sad, lame version that almost no one can find anything redeeming about.
If you want to play the best C&C game then go find the original C&C here on Steam. It has been remastered and runs great on modern PCs. 
You'll be glad you did!
